Bottle. Light yellow, very small fully diminishing head. Very light malty sweetish aroma with notes of corn/rice. Very light body, lightly malty and lightly sweetish and flat aroma, faint grassy hoppyness.  Finish is short malty and flat. Yes, you can also drink rice.
Good lager. All around good taste. Not the best I have had but will definitely drink again I’m sure.

Bottle.  Pours very light yellow with a small, rocky white head, quickly diminishing with light lacing.  Aroma is average malt (straw, hay, grain, meal), light hops (spicy), and light esters (fruity) with notes of sweat and vegetable.  Flavor is average malt (straw, hay, grain, meal), light hops (spicy), and light esters (fruity) with notes of sweat and vegetable.  Light body and warmth, medium carbonation, light creaminess with a slick, watery finish.
Tsingtao is not bad at all. The German’s took Qingdao from the Chinese during WWI (correct me if I am wrong), and set up their own brewery. Pretty cool story isn’t it? German beer brewed in China.
Clear light golden with a creamy white head. Aromas include light malts, acidity, fruity artificial esters. Instant blandness, sweet and bitter. Sticky. Light body. Medium carbonation.

Appearance:  clear sunny gold; small head that shrinks to nothing; no appreciable lace.  Aroma:  smells of cut grass and pepper; almost pilsner-y.  Taste:  taste is almost completely of plain carbonation, with a whisper of grains.  Finish:  nonexistent.  Notes:  Like a mineral water flavored with beer extract.
0.3L bottle. Light gold - almost no carbonation. Light sugar in the aroma. Taste is lacking, with a slight plastic aftertaste.

330 ml bottle. Rated @ 12.12.2009.

Clear yellow colour with a white head. Aroma of pale malts and some hops. Flavour of malts and mild hops. Nothing else. Watery mouthfeel. Premium? Yeah, this is a real premium brew.

Tsingtao has a medium, white head and a very clear, deep golden appearance.  Carbonation is moderate.  The aroma is stereotypical lager, with that nice beer smell.  Taste is a good balance of barley and hops; round and well made.  Mouth-feel is light and watery, and Tsingtao finishes crisp and refreshing.  Overall, I really enjoyed this one, and was happy that my sample wasn’t skunked (green bottle).  

RJT

The green bottle makes it hard to get a well kept example. When it is good it is still just OK. Bland lager but not terrible.  When at a Chinese restaurant stick to the Scorpion Bowls and Navy Grog. Serving: Bottle

Bottle @ Yang Tse Kiang Restaurant, Bergen. Pours a pale lager body with a thin white head. Nose is sweet pale malts and corn, rice and grains. Taste is sweet and slightly grainy. Smooth, and rather drinkable, but oh so dull.

Bottle at Z & Y’s, SF. Low on options, that’s when you hit up this beer. And I recall that it was down to this or Tiger, a coin flap of swill. Less offensive than some "premium" lagers, but there’s just nothing to this other than a bit of corn and a hint of hops to battle the heat from the ma po, etc.

330mL greeny with some Chinese food in Brampton. 4.8%. . Clear watery yellow pour with a moderate white foam, little retention. Aroma is skunky hops, grainy. Taste is barley, mild hoppy dryness, and overall fairly plain. Finish is a little rocky, astringent, but not terrible..
A lighter beer with some serious skunk to it. It’s definitely drinkable, but there’s nothing but skunk to it.
bottle. i thought all premium/pale lagers were alike. not this one. this was worse to me. no flavours, or distinct aromas, and weak in the mouth.

12 oz bottle into footed pilsner glass. "Tsingtao Beer has a pleasant aroma." That’s what it says up there in the description. That’s pretty hilarious. Skunk is only faint, which is a surprise given the green glass. The more offensive odor in this beer is something both chemical-like and vomit-like that I can’t quite pinpoint. I’m in for a treat here, I can tell already. Pours a clear pale gold with a two finger head that vanishes very quick, leaving a small collar of foam and barely-there lace. The stinky aroma has disappeared now at least. Taste is slightly sweet and salty with no bitterness. Taste is very standard. They have this listed under "premium lager" on this website, but it’s no different than any other bland pale lager. Highly carbonated, thin body and watery. It’s better than the Estrella Damm I had before this, or even something like Heineken. Apart from the initial rank odor, this is more similar in style to U.S. macros like Bud than it is to any of the Euro lagers. Looking back on my past scores, both the Estrella and Heineken received a better score from me than this, even though if forced to choose one of these three crap beers, I would pick this hands down. Because of the terrible appearance of this beer, it gets a lower score. That’s one of the major flaws of Ratebeer, when beers you don’t think of too highly get better scores than beers that are just slightly better.

33cl bottle.  
@home.  Not much to say about this beer.  It’s an ok lager.  Not my usual tipple
Nose is pretty much water, tastes very dry and crisp with a hint of residual sweetness.
Pours a pale golden color.  Foamy white head.  Smells skunky.  Taste, however, is fruity and sweet.  Quite different from aroma.  Not a huge fan but it was free :)
This right on the level of the American macro stuff. Very slight malt taste, everything else is skunk. Not nearly one of the worst beers I’ve had, but it isn’t very good.
Pale lager, premium lager, a rare few are worth a damn, and this doesn’t nearly resemble one of them

Medium white head. Paleish yellow body. Light oily grassy papery aroma with toffee notes. Dryish papery mealy strawy grassy taste with toffee notes. Light body. Mild, smoothish mouthfeel. Dryish papery grassy aftertaste. Fairly clean, although bad off-flavours settle in the mouth after a while. Bloody hell! They actually put hops in this. Could be a lot worse. (0.33l bottle, Meny Grønland, Oslo.)

Bottle at Indian Summer, Brighton, 14th July 2010. Piss yellow with an attempt at some head. Weak nose, bit of cardboard & paper. Bland, weak and watery macro lager taste. This is a "Thatcher" beer - only drink when *there is no alternative*!
Very pale, watery and thin, very little on flavour, although it does have quite a nice subtle aroma, seems to appear in quite a lot of chinese restaurants nowadays

Tsingtao beer. How can I say this nicely. It sucks. It’s not the worst beer that I’ve had but it certainly isn’t what I would call a good one. I’ll start with the appearance. It’s a clear golden yellow color. The head that is there is white, but there’s barely any head to begin with and what is present has no retention. It has a hoppy aroma, but that in and of itself isn’t too strong. It may have been the environment that I was in masking the aroma, but I doubt it. It has a thin body with a mild to low carbonation. The flavor was disappointing as well. It has a slight tint of malt but the thin body doesn’t retain the flavor very well so it was mainly a bitter tasteless feel. Overall I hope that China has better beer than this because this is a total bust.

Short-lived head... that or I didn’t pour right for a Tsingtao!  Big-bubbled carbonation.  Served cold and crisp.  Pale yellow, very clear.  A little too much like an American pilsner.  It is what it is, I suppose.  Not as metallic as I expected.  Non-offensive flavor.  Clean and cold, lightly bitter with a pretty bitter finish.

Damn you Satan, maybe my bottle was skunked, but damn you either way. Bottled pee all the way from China. No aroma, pale lager pee color, no palate, and a putrid skunky taste. Got a 2 overall because it was free. One beer to avoid at all costs.
Bottle a yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts water and bitterness taste malts water and some bitterness

Bottle. Very pale yellow colour, small white head. Some light grainy maltiness and rice in the aroma. Quite sweet taste has some bitterness in the end. Very light bodied. Suitable with some spicy oriental food in the restaurant but maybe not on it’s own.
Bottle 33cl. A clear yellow beer with white head. A very basic lager, not exceptional with low body but easy to drink, very common.

(Bottle at some Chinese restaurant in Stockholm, 29 May 2010) Pale yellow colour with frothy, white head. Malty nose with grain, hay and rice. Malty taste with notes of bread, grain, grass and a touch of citrus. Low bitterness, rather thin body and fairly sweet. No foul flavours, just thin, sweet and fairly boring.

12oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours light golden with quickly vanishing white head.  Aroma of bread and wood chips that is common for this style of beer.  Don’t really taste any hops in this one.  Not that good.  Don’t drink unless you have to.
Head diminishes almost immediately. Weak and skunky fodder for Chinese food with elements of corn. Predictably rubbish.

Very soft and has some maybe honey taste. On some occasions I taste there just pure alcohol, which is weird. Anyway, very normal taste, nothing bad. Very comfortable soft taste, not at all watery. Though, a bit bitter long time after drinking, and it’s not nice. [330 ml bottle, 4,7 %]

Bottle as shown. Pours a clear golden with small frothy white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is a corn malt and wheat grass. Thin mouthfeel with a bitter malt and bitter finish, not much going on with this one.
Nothing special but goes down nice.   A bit watered down which makes this a perfect session beer to pound as you cut the grass.
(can) clear, pale golden colour with tiny white head; aroma of sweetish grain; flavour  is weak and watery, faintly sweet with hint of short bitter finish

12oz bottle from a local Chinese restaurant 

Appearance: Pours a clear light golden with a very small white head, no lacing 

Aroma: Pale malts and honey 

Taste: Yeasty, corn and sweet malts 

Nice Lager, clean and crisp.
bottle - typical oriental lager although not as sweet as most. Great ice cold on a hot day or for washing down fried rice at the local Dimsum joint.

When we think of China, beer is not usually one of the things that come to mind. But if we must name a Chinese beer, Tsingtao is pretty much the only one most people (connoisseurs included) can name. As is the case with most countries, their most popular beer is a completely generic, uninspired, pale lager. 

POUR, COLOR AND AROMA

This brew pours rather rough to a bright white gold, clear complexion. It’s bristling with carbonation and forms a one-finger, bright white, fizzy head which dissolves quickly and almost completely. The carbonation also calms down rather quickly. The scent is a bit skunky, which isn’t surprising considering the fact it’s packaged in green bottles. Compared to others of the style it’s actually quite subdued, but otherwise there isn’t much worth mentioning since it’s just a typical grainy “beer smell.”

TASTE

In the United States, certain macro breweries like to market their beers as tasting “crisp” and/or “clean” as if such adjectives were compliments. I would use both to describe the taste of Tsingtao. This is a pale lager, after all, supposedly based on the German pilsner style. Those looking for something distinct in the palate will have a tough time finding anything.

Surprisingly, this beer does not have a rice-like flavor since rice is apparently not used as an adjunct ingredient. The bottle boasts “only the highest quality malted barely, hops, yeast, and pure mountain water…” If this is the highest quality China has to offer, I’d hate to taste what the lesser-quality beers taste like. However, it does have a slightly sweet taste, but it’s extremely faint. Like most lagers of the type, water seems to be the predominant flavor.

FINISH

With a very soft mouthfeel and a smooth, easy finish, it’s not hard to understand why Tsingtao is such a popular brew. I’ve come to the conclusion that drinkers, en masse, would much prefer a smoother brew to a tasty one.

BODY

This beer drinks and tastes like a typical American light lager, and yet it’s a bit heavier at 4.8% ABV and 157 calories per serving. I drank a 22oz bomber bottle very quickly and felt almost no effects whatsoever. 

FINAL THOUGHTS

There isn’t much to appreciate about Tsingtao and yet it’s not a beer that’s easy to hate, in fact, my reaction is almost complete indifference. I think it would work fine a session beer, or as a compliment to Chinese food, but otherwise there’s very little here to enjoy.

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d9caOYDDaAc

Bottle 330 ml from Casino Supermarket in Cernier (CH). Pale blond without foam, fizzing average to weak. Sweet smell of cereals, cream and vanilla key. It is really thin, watery, but not unpleasant and well made. Final short, sweetish and bitter touch

640ml bottle from Tesco Extra. Rice & resin aroma. (fond memories of China) Very pale yellow colour, not much head. Resin rice & corn flavour. Watery but sharp lager. Great for washing down oriental food. Not a beer to savour.

We oz bottle pour. Thin pale gold with pure white head. Says lager, smells of pilsner. Taste is thin with a little bitter on the end and some sweetness in the middle that tastes fruity. Really did remind me of a pilsner.
330ml bottle served at a Chinese place in Stavanger. Pale body, head and taste. Aroma?

330 ML bottle in Germany, Beer was beeter than expected. Light golden color with laced head. Aroma was very nice and fruity. Taste was the same. Palate was disapointing and very short. Beer has a very watery palate and teaste after the initial burst of fruit.

Unoffensive and unimpressive.  Very pale body with virtually no head.  The aroma is light and sweet with a touch of apple.  Thin palate with light carbonation.  The flavor is smooth but bland.  Light and moderately sweet.  No bitterness to speak of.  Meh.

(330ml bottle) very pale yellow with oily white head so afraid of the beer it runs away quickly. Nose of apple and that’s it. Is this a cider? Taste of cereal grains, butter, light apple and old. Nothing Terribly offensive and nothing good. Light body but not too watery with decent carbonation. Not terrible for a pale lager but not good at all.

A- typical golden body with no head macro appearance. The golden is a nice color.

S- this is the worst smell I have ever experienced in my life for a beer. skunky and revolting. I still ventured to take a sip.

T- not nearly as bad as it smells. pretty boring with somewhat of a bitter hop bite.

O- easy to drink but the smell makes you not want to drink it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-13-2007 14:43:04

Bottle 330ml. Pours a pale golden color with small white head. Low to medium carbonation. Tastes malty, some citrus, grass and a hint of honey. Very (too?) watery in my opinion. Nothing special, but no unpleasant aftertaste either. Not impressive at all.

LIght gold pour, bubbly white head. Aroma is mostly light malt, grain, a touch of honey, and light floral hops. Flavor is much of the same, with barley and grain the dominant characteristics. Very light mouthfeel typical of the style. Not bad.
This beer smells very skunky. Pours a light pee color with a very small - almost non-discernible white head. Tastes salty and lightly sour.
Typical lager, easy to drink nothing to remember afterthe bottle is finished. OK for lunch to flush down the food with.
Bouteille, bière blonde commerciale mais très agréable avec des plats relevés de l’Asie. Léger goût de houblon agréable, rafraichissante à souhait. une bonne Lager commerciale.

Not great. Looks like water. A light golden colour with no head. Aroma is very bready. Tastes like it looks, very little flavour and no impact whatsover on the palette. Even as a mass produced lager it ain’t great.
Bottle at home. Very pale golden pour, almost no head. Grainy skunked aroma and a very skunked watery flavor. No finish. Average carbonation. Quite dull.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
Pours a pale gold with a very small foamy white head.  The head doesn’t last long.  Really struggled to get much from the nose on this one.  Some stale grain and cardboard notes were about it.  The taste is decidely bland with those oxidized notes carrying over in the flavor.  An unrewarding bitterness chimes in too.  The overaggressive carbonation doesn’t seem to help matters.  Light on the palate with a weak, medium-short finish.  Definitely pass this brew by.

Pale goldish yellow, medium soapy head.
Aroma is very fresh with some hops at first but becomes extremely faint  very quickly. Flavour is disappointing, watery with a weird bitterness.
No drain pour but that’s it.

Bottle in China and at home in Sweden some years ago.

Typical light lager, clear golden with a small head.

Thin aroma and flavor, watery and boring. Some grass and bread, dry.

12 oz. pour from bottle.  Low malt, low hops, low flavor.  Still, for a beer from China (not exactly known for its beer making) it wasn’t too bad.  Had one at a Chinese joint with my dinner.  Actually went pretty well together.
bottle - pale yellow beer with no head. Cardboard in a thin aroma. Flavour is watery and little bit boring. Low bitterness. Medium carbonation.

Pours a pale yellow with a white head.  Aroma is a slightly sweet grain but nothing more.  Pretty much the same when it comes to taste.  Not a horrible beer, but nothing good at the same time.  Probably the only decent selection when you go to a chinese restaurant anyway, but even then, I would just get the tea.

Suped up typical lager.  Aroma seems to be missing. Has a crisp distinct taste that makes it stand out. Evidence of hops is present and the beer relaxes on the sweet adjuncts. Taste different and distinct but overall a bit boring.

Bland and tasteless for the most part. To be fair there is a bit of a lager taste at the beginning that turns into a rice aftertaste. For what it’s worth I found this more enjoyable than any of the japanese rice beer macro offerings. Goes OK with Chinese food.

Bottle.  Pours clear super-light golden.  Nose is grainy/grassy.  Nothing special here, but better than water when you’re eating spicy Chinese.  Many other better Asian "premium" lagers from which to choose.
Typical light style lager.  Light golden color with little head.  Very crips tasting , which makes it refreshing.  Decent for the style.

This tastes like the Chinese equivalent of the American macrobrews, only slightly better. Maybe that’s the mercury in their water. I could see this being a decent session beer for those who like pale lagers.
330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a light yellow gold with thin white head.  Aroma is mild grains/grass.  Taste is a little stronger but same profile.  Fairly thin body.  Meh.

Draft. Glassy, pale gold with beige head. Not a bad aroma, is grassy, metallic and slightly minerally. Itï¿½s all downhill from there. The palate is practically flat. The flavors are not so bad, with bland cereals, and grass in the finish. A touch sour but not so bad. 4-3-3-1-7 = 1.8




Green bottle: Clear yellow with scant head. Aroma is phenolic with varnish, paint thinner but bland enough. Very thin palate. Bland beer with sweet corn aftertaste. 3-2-3-2-6 = 1.6
Bland lagery aroma and look. Palate quite sweet and lychee-like retronasals. Body quite watery, but crisp. Slight papery hops, but not offensive. A touch corny in places, fortunately no poop.
Bottle. Pale straw color with white head. malty aroma. Flavor is corny, mechanic hoppy. Maybe over pasteurized. Drinkable - for one time

Pretty much I can’t believe I have to give this .5 as it looks like piss no head. Aroma is skunky with a bitter metallic taste. I hate to think what the Chinese put in this I guess I will find out depending on how long I live.

Bottle.  LIght yellow with quickly fading head.  Vegetable and sweet malt but very weak aroma. Waterly, some fruit, but not much more.  Short finish.  Goes well with oily, spicy or salty Chinese food.
Nothing special about this one.  Yellowish clear color.  Aroma is of malts, rice, a slight skinked flavor, and stale hops.  Flavor is the same.  Thank god I don’t have to drink this again.

33cl bottle, local store. Pours clear very pale yellow color, very fast fading thin white head. Aroma is very faint, sweet malty i´d say. Flavour reminds me of cardboard and some cheap white wine with a slight bitterness in the finish. Odd taste in mouth afterwards. Overall not as bad as one could think from the points IMO.
I’ve had a few Asian lagers and many have some redeeming quality.  Not this one.  Pretty awful skunk aroma, skunk flavor, watery mouthfeel.  Offensive.

Pours clear pale yellow with a white frothy head.  Aromas of grains and sugar, maybe a small amount of hops.  The flavor is very mild with cereal grains being the most notable.  This beer was actually much better than I anticipated it to be.
Bottle.  Pours a pale golden body with a white head.  Adjunctive with some light vegetative notes, grain, and some light floral notes.  An easy session ale that paired well with Tai.
Bottle, given to me.....FREE...... I drank half of it, just weak with little to no taste. I have become a beer snob I am told.

12oz bottle at a Chinese restaurant. Golden color, no surprise there. It didn’t have much smell in the glass at all. The flavor was surprisingly better than average with a fruitiness that I was not expecting from a macro Chinese lager. Great beer to pair with hot and sour soup.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-19-2009 04:23:41

(cl-btl, gl/rd-lbl)



lct-yw, §bitter throughout, very bland and watery.

like drinking water out of last night’s unrinsed beer glass.

12 oz at the evocatively named szichuanese restaurant in the id. pours a crystal clear slightly burnished medium gold. tons of sparkling nucleation columns and a fizzy, short lived white head. mildly skunky, somewhat corny aroma. fizzy, watery body with slippery bits here and there. nutty, corny, corn nutty and slightly skunky mid palate. mild finish. i happily inhale these at chinese places, despite a rather striking mediocrity. i always like to pretend i know how to pronounce the name like a real mandarin speaker. maybe that adds to it.

Bottle. P. F. Changs Tucson AZ
light zesty pour with a thin head. Light. Corn wheat barley light in the hopps dept. Very flavorful for a light beer. Goes very well with Chinese food!

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thin short lived head over a yellow (SRM 4) body.....nose of light malts with a bit of corn.....tastes of light slightly sweet malt to start, finishing with very light hop bitterness....mouth feel light and slightly watery, carbonation medium to high. A very light beer even for the Premium Lager style, perhaps this should be called a Pale Lager.
Not much going on here. Viturally no head at all. Mild hoppy aroma with a light straw colored body. Drank smooth with hardely any finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear, pale golden yellow with a thin white ring.  Very delicate aroma of faint grains and mild floral hops.  Taste is slightly sweet malt flavor overlaid with hops, bread and grain; finish is mildly bitter.
Poured a bright yellow with no head to speak of.  Aroma was weak.  Serviceable as a palate cleanser, had it with a dim sum lunch.  Made a nice team with my glass of water and cup of tea.
bottle 4.5%.  Poured clear very pale yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of sulpher. Average carbonation. Light mouthfeel. Flavour is grainy with a little malt. Medium bitterness. Not’n special.
The whole beer could be described with a single word: Corn ... Nothing special at all. It’s nice ;only with spicy food.
Decent cheap asian beer. Very much corn taste and a tangy aftertaste. Tastes very pale, kinda like a heineken.
330ml Bottle - Golden with moderate carbonation. Grainy aroma with malt and grass. Malty taste with corn, grass and a light bitterness.

Nový Bor, Czech Republic, bottle 8 C - not a nice experience, ordered a Krusovice before finishing half the bottle.
Pale gold (urine), head diminishing.
Dry and not interessting flavors = water. Don’t purchase!
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours clear gold. Aroma of hops, hay, wheat, and citrus. Thin body. Quick finish. Very poor lager.
Pours a light yellow. Flavour is mildly hoppy, with citrus and yeast. Standard, unimaginative pale lager.

piss colored pour...white head goes away fast. tastes like someone took a Heineken, and removed what little flavor was there, then presented me with this. good mouthfeel but that is the only positive. lingers badly on the palate.

Lo mein, Fried Rice, Dumplings, Sweet & Sour, Chow Mein, Beef with Broccoli, Chicken with cashews...

MMMMMMmmmmm

I think I still have spare ribs stuck in my tooth.
Golden Yellow Pour with minimal head. Aroma of hops. Not much lacing. Flavor reminded me of a lighter Heineken. OVerall I didn’t mind this beer, not my favorite, but not bad at all.
Bottled in a restaurant.  Very standard, pale blonde lager, in-offensive but bland watery bitterness.  Just another lager.
Poured a pale yellow liquid with a medium sized white foam. It was very watery and didn’t have much taste,

Pours a clear light yellow with white head. Aroma is citrus, yeast and grass. Flavor is nutty in flavor but a watered down nuttiness, notes of vanilla. All falvor is very watery. Body is extremely light with high carbonation.
This is my first Asian beer.  Wasn’t too impressed by China’s effort, but it was better than I expected.

Bottle.  Pours a lovely pale gold with a very small and ephemeral head.   After just a couple of seconds I’m wondering if it was even ever there.  Aromas of skunky hops assault me from a distance and closer inspection confirms that these are burying any other odors except for a few whiffs of apple juice that are scurrying for the exit doors.  Flavor is poor... a bit of apple juice, some adjuncty-lagery malt and those damn hops seem to have fled while the getting was good.  I’m not sure about this "spring water from Laoshan." I don’t really know if it added anything, and I’m begining to think it might be a simple marketing trick...  Even so, if they handed these out for free at work I’d probably drink another.

Pours a golden yellow with a sweet, corny aroma. It tastes of sweet, corny malt and slightly bitter hops with an overall sweet characteristics. This isn’t my favourite, but it’s a good beer nonetheless.

A refreshing and sweet beer. Not particularly light and not particularly hoppy. This is a great entry into Asian been as it is readily available. Not necessarily the best Asian beer readily available, but readily available none the less.

drank from the bottle: Tastes pretty much like Heineken, though perhaps a bit smoother. You can taste the rice lager. But still its an easy drink and its still beer. I got it in a trade for some of my cheap homebrew, so I can’t complain.
bottle: pint glass: NI HAO!!! ouch this stuff is rough!!!  Why do all beers in green glass taste like licking the sweat glands of skunk roadkill?!

When all is said and done, this is pretty bad stuff, perhaps no better than a Bud and certainly inferior to an Iron City despite its more exotic reputation.  It is a mass market macro brewery rice lager.  It has only the smallest head, and leaves no lacing; just plain ugly.  Nose of rice and grain, with barely a hint of hops, thin watery mouth, taste of rice and malts and barely a hint of hops ... just nasty stuff even if served with an exotic Beijing banquet.  Feh.
Chinese Heineken... you know - Chinaken!  Really not great stuff - everything you’d expect out of a lager in a green bottle.

i guess for the quantity of this they brew it is not bad... it is watery at best, acid white head gone in seconds and the flavor (which is very faint) is certainly not going to upset anyone.  i probably would not ever buy it but VPB brought some over to my house and hey, free beer is always good beer in my book. :-)

Bottle @ Noble House into lager glass.  Pours a warm yellow with a decent white head that quickly deflates.  Not much carbonation at all.  Very sweet, corny and kind of banana/warm grain smell and taste.  Not awesome but not a drain pour.
Light, smooth, but lacks fragrance and character.  Ok with Chinese food but doesn’t stand much on its own.

Very clear with a light golden color, high carbonation and a small, thin, white head. A light note of noble hops and a lot of grain notes with a light sweet and sour note. Flavor is really grainy, sweet with a light spicy hops.  Very thin and just not much to it. Overall not bad but thing that is really unique about it.
Bottle. Pours very pale, with almost no head at all. Some hops in the nose. Dry crisp taste. Nothing special.

This was not too bad for a swill, in fact rather better than expected.  Colour, head, and aroma were all pretty much swill-standard, but flavour and mouthfeel were a touch better.  I’d have it again.
Re-reviewed: after having this stuff in the homeland (China), it seems a touch better than that which I’ve had at home.  Maybe they keep the good stuff for their ’home’ market?
smells fairly gross and the palate is quite awful. But it’s one of those beers that isn’t very bad when you’re eating, but not something to look forward to really. China has many better beers.
A bottle 0.33L 4.7%. Pale fast disappearing head. Mild hoppy nose. Bright pale hey colour. Mild waterly and sour taste.  Some hints of lemon. Very mild hops.
Very pale yellow, rapidly disappearing white head.  Not much aroma.  Very light body, some bitterness, but completely forgettable.
Just another tasteless macro offering for the masses. Slightly better than the other Chinese beers I have tried so far, so I see why it gets exported.

Bottle.  Poured a nice golden color with a thin whicte head.  Aroma is very skunky with some sweet malt and hop notes standing out.  The taste was very light and refreshing, but it had a skunky aftertaste.  Better than an American Macro, but not by much.
Bottle, Honolulu. Surprised at how much I enjoyed this beer. Not much to say. Well balanced, full lager. For the price, this is great.

33cl bottle poured into a lager glass.  Sparkling straw with one finger white head.  Aroma is skunky hops and, believe it or not, watermellon.  Very light flavor, yet quite balanced between malt and hops.  Medium carbonation.  A bit watery.  Not bad though.

Bottle 33cl.
Drank from the bottle.
Hoppy easy and fresh aroma.
Taste is about the same, not very special, but certainly drinkable.
From bottle. I sometimes buy this on a chinese restaurant, ans always regrets. Why can’t I remember??

12 oz bottle. Pours pale yellow with almost no head. It has a crisp hop aroma. It tastes a little of cereal and hay with no skunky taste. This isn’t a bad beer but it is just another pale fizzy macro brewery lager.
Basic macro lager, a little fruity taste with plenty of corn and rice all over it, no real head. Had a chance to re-rate and while it’s drinkable enough it’s still below average.
Pours gold with thin white head.  Smell is malty with hint of skunk.  Pretty much a macro ale like you Bud or MGD.  Drinkable, but not anything to get excited about.

The first "illegal" I had at an actual restaurant at Ocean City more than a decade ago...this one is going to be more professionally sampled...straw colored, almost "light" in its presentation--an effervescence helps offset thinness and the runny, weak head... yeasty bread dominates with the ping of Saaz hops as its butter--almost hints that something is amiss... presents a bland blanket of smoothness akin to water to the mouth, with little early or late that suggests this is a beer... such a light body leads to an almost phantom taste, a pilsneresque presence minus the snap of Eastern European brew... without really finding blemish, Tsing Tao finishes crisp but not sharp; one senses rice or corn int he tank here, but no skunk infiltrates... stays balanced throughout the 22 oz. bottle, never bitter or malty despite its aroma...
11.2 oz bottle. Dark yellow with no head. Almost no carbonation. Sickly sweet corn nose, malty. Sweet flavor, body is pretty dead. Meh.

Bottle from a local Thai restaurant. Pours a light yellow color with thin head. Aroma is light with notes of grass, wet hay, some light yeast hints of honey. Flavor is light as well with notes of grass, yeast, honey, slight floral hop notes toward finish. Generally light body with watery finish. Not bad for a pale lager.

The new fancy looking bottle makes this appear better but it’s not. The agressive pour still didn’t produce a cap that lasted more than 10 seconds. Nothing now. Pretty weak gold for colour but it is very clear. The aroma is mainly grains. Nothing offensive here as the smell seems fairly clean but it needs more and is just plain. Taste is pretty grainy with some nice bitterness on the finish but watery overall. Mouthfeel is decent with a foamy swish. Light bodied. Short lived mild bitter aftertaste. Reliable but boring.
Pours brightly clear and yellow. Skunky nose mixes with grain. The taste is really grainy, and lacks much beyond that. Pretty boring, but serves its purpose I guess.

Appearance: Pours out a brilliant, light yellow body with a frothed, white head.

Smell: Initial skunk whiff. Let me do the Jumble and I’ll be right back. Alright, now that that’s blown away, we can get some faint maltiness, cereal sweetness, and a light touch of plain floral hops.

Taste: Faint maltiness with some standard cereal sweetness. Very mild floral hops with just a minimal, though growing amount of bitterness. Finishes dry and clean with a dainty crispness.

Mouthfeel: Thin-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Just another forgettable, faceless lager from China that makes me really wish I had some Chinese grub to pair with it. Mongolian Chicken, Pork Lo Mein, Moo Goo Gai Pan -- bring it on. Heck, I’ll even go for Broccoli Beef!

Date: May 23, 2009

Mode: Bottle

Source: Ticker Tasting

Appearance: clear yellow, fine white head, drippy lace

Aroma: sweet cereal and corn aroma, touch of green apple, light hops

Body: creamy body

Flavor: sweet cereal malt flavor, balancing bitterness, green apple, light bitter finish

Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 5/20

Rating: 1.8/5.0
Drinkability: 4/10

Score: 4

Bottle @ Chinese restaurant. Pours piss golden with a white shiny head. Honey malty smell with some hops, yes hops! Good first sips but the most dull palate ever. Very dead beer but no off-tastes so decent for a lager.
Garbage!!!!! this beer sucks. Really awful. Dont buy it.
Bottle. Pale flat golden with no head visable. Grain and light hop notes. Same flavour. Thin bodied. Light bitterness in the finish. One glass is enough thanks.

Bottle at Mandarin Gourmet in Palo Alto, where it was that or BMC.  Golden-yellow color with a fizzy white head.  Aroma of pale malt and grains with the slightest hint of hops.  Flavor is the same, thoroughly unremarkable but no worse than you’d expect.  Palate OK but a bit watery.  Could be worse (cough, BMC, cough!).
What do you expect from a beer that you get in a nuddle bar? Too easygoing and mediocre taste.

bottle, brought to me by a friend, who bought in in Romania... Clear pale yellow, small white head. Malty-sweet nose. Sweetish-malty flavours dominate with hints of rice. Slightly hoppy with hints of cardboadr and dust. Leaves a strange mouthfeel, even after drinking it.
has a pleasant aroma and a well-balanced taste. It has high-malty flavor and well-hopped character...it is what it is...

4/14/2009:  After finishing the bottle, I nearly forgot that I had even had a beer to drink!  Tsingtao is dry, nearly flavorless, and generally unmemorable.  It would be difficult if not impossible to make a distinction between this beer and any other mass-produced macro lager.




12 fl. oz. bottle at Chi Thai Restaurant in Columbus, Ohio.  Rating #980 for this beer.
Bottle. Pours light gold with a frothy white head. The taste is a light mix of hops and a sweet malt. Not much going on here, pretty lame.

burp!! well the smell is ... ackkk wet...
srry i snifed up the foam wich is snow white, smells grassy verry crisp and hoppy, reminds me of stella artois, tastes great verry crisp refreshing promenent hoppy taste, i am curently doing some spring gardening, it is 80 
some degrees out and this is amazeingly thirst qunching. foam is short lived but lovely, 15 mins later and it is still fizzing. overall iiiits gggrrreeaaatttt! ... coppyright of tony the tiger. lol (yes iv had about 11 of these so far)

Nice colour, thin white head. No retention. Aroma is malty with notes of cardbaord. Flavour is very malty, but not very impressive. It has a good moth feel and carbonation. very crisp and clean. Typical Asian lager. The history of the brewery is probably the best thing about the beer. All in all I think its pretty good. I would rather drink Tsing tao than any Labatt/molson products.

330ml bottle. Highly carbonated with small bubbles that stick to the side of the glass in clusters. Thin white veil of foam. Clear and sparkling golden colour with a heavy malt and hop aroma. Crisp taste that is short lived. Feels silky and smooth in the mouth. Low bitterness.

The aroma is very sharp and smells strongly of hops and cardbord-iness. You could easily read through it. The flavour isn’t too strong but comes on nicely with hops and lots of caronation. Fairly smooth, but also quite mellow. A good drink for the hot sun. Also can be seen with the old bottle in the movie "Bloodsport" with JCVD. It’s Van-Dam good beer!

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Huge amount of skunk as the bottle opened. Pours a clear pale golden with a medium frothy head. Poor head retention and lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, grain. Taste is sweet, grainy malts, corn, rice, very subtle grass. Thick mouthfeel but thin bodied. Slightly watery.
bottle, very small head fading away immediately, almost no head? Rice, watery, some kind of refreshing. My first Chinese beer. I don’t know if they have better ones.

Pours a pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is a little skunky, possibly a little light struck from being in a green bottle and an open 6 pack. Some musty saaz hops and pepper show through with some boiled vegetables and a little corn. Tastes very musty, almost too musty. Over boiled vegetables and a floral perfume like mid palate. Peppers and corn are there as well. Palate is well, forced carbonated... What else can I say. I’d drink it again but only if I had to.
Pours a golden yellow color with a white head.  Aroma is honey, floral, a hint of grain, and peppery hops.  Flavor is honey, floral, and a light peppery finish.

Another skunky foreign lager. Light notes of grass, grain, and some very distant peppery hops. Very clean but drab flavor. Watered down quite a bit. No doubt like their toys this contains lead as well.

Sampled on 3/22/2009. This Pale lager pours a fizzy gold beer color from a 640ml green bottle. Small sized, quickly dissipating foamy head. The aroma is horrid, skunk, urine, cereal, some malt and then some artificial chemical smell, wet dog and cardboard, it does settle down to a bad euro lager smell after a while. A light bodied Pale Lager. The malts are cereal and grainy, with a bunch of rice. The hops are slightly spicy. Very weak and watery tasting. There is an overall taste of cardboard and wet dog as it warms. Is this supposed to be a Chinese version of Heineken? Its just horrid. Mouthfeel is thin. Finish is crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Bottle 33cl, 4.5%. Apperance; Light golden, clear with a minimal head, almost no sparkling. Aroma; Very little, some hops, with a light bitter ending. boring

12oz bottle.   Gold with a small, dissipating head.   Lightly skunky, grassy aroma.   Pale malt flavors with light hop flavor and bitterness.   Dry fiinish.   Light bodied.   If the bottle had been kept out of the light, this would be a pretty smooth pale lager.   Decent enough for what it is.
Bottle. Pours a typical lager golden yellow, soapy white head. Aroma is very vague hops, touch of malt. Flavor is slightly sweet malt, hops in the background. Thin body, very slight bitterness.

No 707

Rated: 06.03.2009

Bottlebottle green, 330 ml

Appearance: This is it beer in fact? The previous Chinese beers I’ve had, had some head at least, aren’t so hazy and so flat in carbonation, this one seems to be the most popular but I start to think when I look at it if it really isn’t a beer of the worst quality. It is totally the same beer but in fact it different in their name as the same sensation can be applied to other poor Chinese beers.

Aroma: Some accidity plus cane sugar, very weak and poor, no hops, no malt, almost non existant, it is a waste of time to drink it.

Flavour: Very similar to water, a total industrail swill, very cane and total failure denoting only totally watered down adjuncts like cron and rice. Horrible nasty, poor aftertaste of cane sugar mixed with barley carbonated industrial water.

Palate: Body is light, texture is wattery, carbonation on palate is weak, this beer really drives me creazy.

Pours a pale yellow with white head.  This beer tastes awful, but the aroma is even worse.  I don’t know what it is (rotten vegetables?) but it’s strong and potent.  It reminds me of when you try beer for for the first time and you’re all like "eeewww, gross beer!" before you discover that there actually is god beer out there.
Not bad; a hint of a bitter aftertaste but it quickly disappears.  An easy drinker.

Very pale body and lifeless head.
Drinkable, but smells very skunky, some butter and hop taste. Think Corona for sure.

Bottle.  Pours gold with a small fizzy head.  Smells of grain and small malts.  Tastes of very light grain or malt, and a very light spicey hops.  Although its very light on smell and taste, its very good and worth trying.  Nice stuff.

I have absolutely nothing to contribute about this beer so I will istead mention that this beer was featured in Jean Claude Van Damme’s bloodsport. However, I don’t remember JCVD actually drinking this, there are some pints with some beer in them and Tsingtao bottles near so I don’t think it would be unreasonable to deduce that they had been drinking it. Tsingtao is better than sol and corona but worse than westvleteren. I guess there might be some hops in the taste and something ricey but all this is just wasting air. It is drinkable and works on a hot day but so is water. Well not all water but you get the point.
Light in everyway. Easy to drink and pair with foods. Not impressive though. Attraction would be its utter simplicity.
bright appearance with fast-off head. smell of hops and grass. sweet start, mid comes with some hops, ends hopsy and a bit malty, allover a very thin taste
0.33 bottle, Light aroma, yellow colour, light head, taste is quite nothing, surprised about the palate. No reason to drink this asgain though.
Bottle. Pours a weak yellow color. Very weak watery taste. Aroma is skunk and malts. Taste is malts and water. Not very good beer.
Weak malt aroma. Clear yellow colour wit small white head. Sweet, but otherwise an ordinary lager.

Not bad for a generic Asian lager. A decent, if uncomplicated drink, suitable as an ice cold refresher on a warm day. Predictably goes well with spicy Asian foods as the blandness doesn’t detract from the food.
Bottle. Very weak watery beer to go with your chinese food. Giving it one point higher than Bud just because.
Very pale yellow color. Taste almost like water. Very very light taste. Not bad but not the greatest beer.
Pee colored pour, almost no head. Corny, apple juice aroma. Flavor is shockingly not skunky, grainy and corny though with some light grassy hops. Chinese Bud.

Pours a clear pale yellow with a very small white head.  Aroma is very grainy with a very faint hoppy character.  The body is extremely light and hardly any hops or malts are noticeable.  Very skunky and watery.  To be quite honest, one of the worst beers I’ve ever tried.
12 oz bottle purchased at Frugal MacDoogal’s in Nashville.  Poured a clear yellow color with a thin white head.  The aroma was grainy.  The flavor was watery.  Not a great beer.

Bottle  Pours a clear pale yellow with a diminshing white head.  Aroma is of corn and grains and light hops.  Taste is kind of sweet and forgetable.  Light body and almost no hops or malts.  Not that China is known for great beer but this was not good.

Bottle (thanks mom!). Clear pale golden color with a medium, very bubbly, white head that diminishes fast. Aroma is quite grainy with some corn notes and faint hoppy hints. Sweet flavor of cereals, some creamed corn and really light bitterness in the finish. Light-bodied.

Bottle.  Pours with very pale yellow, almost no head and no aroma (but then, I do have a bit of a cold).  Didn’t have high expectations and was not disappointed, meaning this beer is just plain bad.  Flavor was flat, a little sweet and no hint of any hops at all.  I have another bottle, might try that one to be sure I didn’t get a skunky one, but then I doubt that.  Drain pour...
Bottle 33 cl. Pous a very clear yallow with a small white head and a corny aroma . The taste is very plain and corny too, almost no malts or hops to be detected. I don’t like it.

330 ml bottle. Finland.
Golden colour with no head. 
Very weak aroma. Corn. A bit sweet. Malt. Quite watery.

Can 33 cl. with old-fashioned opener.  Clear an pale yellow pour with a almost-not-there-white-head. The nose is fresh a yeasty with some straws and light citrusnotes and a hint of perfume. The taste likeways with some perfumic soap pvertones.... hmmm this one brings forwards some back-packer memorys but tasted certaintly better at the new garden Hostel in steaming warm dormatories at the Chung King accomodation. Pale and light...

This is a very smooth beer excellent on a warm day. It has a light golden apperance and holds its head reasonably well

The aroma is mildly hoppy, with malt flavours coming through in the aftertaste.
Bottle at home. Apple juice colored. Little head. Flat tasting. Not much flavor, pretty much a weak lager. Bit ricey. Fun to be rating a Chinese beer.

640ml bottle purchased at Albertsons in Harbor Pointe (Mukilteo), WA.  Pours a pale yellow with a foamy white head.  Aroma:  Slight skunky.  Flavor: Moderate hops & malt.  This one would be refreshing on a hot day.
Very pale yellow with a finger of tight white head.  Horrendous skunk aroma, metal.  Taste is thin watery malt.

Typically I don’t put stuff in my mouth made in China. Though not great, this lager exceeded my expectations. Taste/Aroma: fruit, tart, some hops, cereal. It is sort of cider like. Palate is dry and fizzy.

330mL single bottle from the LCBO Stop Pours a pathetically pale yellow with way too much carbonation and fizz Stop As soon as I popped the cap off I could smell skunk, seriously, the very moment the cap came off Stop Wow Stop Bad smelling beer Stop Flavour is actually not bad though, pretty skunky but there is some decent hopppy dryness following some mediocre pale malts Stop Not as bad as I was expecting, and hey at least I can say I have had a Chinese beer, whether that really means much or not Stop I will actually almost enjoy finishing this Stop I will not have to stop drinking it Stop I just wish there was some sort of presence of legitimate craft beers in China and that they would stop making such boring stuff Stop

Pale yellow body with a small white head. Avarage aroma and flavor of a lager beer. Some sweet taste, some grassy bitterness, so an avarage beer from the other side of the world. But  we have thousands of boring lagers, why was that beer delivered to  Europe? The market is not enough in China.... Or what?
Pours light gold with a 1 finger white head that has decent retention. Aroma is grassy, and fresh corn. Flavor is grass, straw, corn. Finish is grassy and somewhat sweet. Lame beer at premium price.
neutral aroma,pale, clear, aminimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, almost no finish....good ample to my collection but not good beer

[Bottled at a chinese reastaurant at Sveavägen, Sthlm]
Golden with a brief, white head. A lot of bubbles.
Pretty fresh mouthfeel.
No bitterness with notes of oranges.
Bland and industrial.

apresenta espuma de aparência inicial média, cor branca e reduzida longevidade. Há boa formação de colarinho em seu corpo borbulhante, de densidade rala e tonalidade amarelo-claro. O aroma traz notas de pão branco e lúpulo moderado. Leve amargor é o que permeia tanto o sabor inicial quanto o final, sendo este de curta duração. No paladar se percebe um corpo leve, de textura aguada, forte carbonatação e final de sensação metálica. Apesar de não apresentar diferenciais, tampouco peca em qualquer quesito, apresentando boa drinkability
Yellow, overly carbonated beer that pretty much tastes like water in every single way. It even smells like water, plus a little metallic. That is right, water has a smell!
It looks like water, smells like water, tastes like water, and even feels like water. Hell, this is either the blandest beer or the best water - not sure which.
Light yellow pour with a fizzy head.  Very light sweet malt aroma and flavor.  Perhaps the reason they mention the Laoshan is that it is the main flavor element.

Very pale yellow beer with lots of loose, fizzy bubbles.  I got a big whiff of skunk as soon as I opened the bottle.  The aroma had skunk, balloon rubber, and sticky sweetness in it.  This is a sweet lager, with corn syrup, table sugar, and cotton candy, with a faint orange note.  Really not much to recommend this, unless you like really sweet beer.

Bottle. Light yellow colour with a thin white head. Hoppy aroma. The flavour is hops, slightly sweet and some malts. For some reason this bottle had much more hops than Tsingtaos normally, so it was actually quite drinkable.
330 ml bottle. Your basic, watery pale lager. Not much to recommend it, but I needed something to wash down the Chinese food with.
12 oz bottle in WDW at the food and wine festival.  It’s the michelob ultra of China - almost unbelievably light and taste-free.
Tried it at a Chines resteraunt. Not very good. Pours kind of flat to a small white head. Somewhat bitter taste that doesn’t get better with more than one. The body is light and the texture dry.

330ml green bottle from my dad. produced on 09/08/08, consumed on 16/11/08.

pours pale yellow with some white head that reduces to a ring. soft carbonation.

aroma: sweet grain and rice, cotton candy

flavour: sweet, a touch of grainy malt, almost nothing to this one

mouthfeel: thin and uninprired

drinkability: i wouldnt say know to a free one but not something id ever purchase, not off flavour other then overly sweet

Bottle (330cl). Straw yellow colour with neglible head. Slight hoppy aroma. Fullish malty palate with hardly any bitterness to finish. Refreshing but there are many better sessionable lagers out there.

Bottle  courtesy  of Dave L
Really you could have kept this one to yourself. YUK how did that skunk get in there
Check out the link below

http://www.break.com/pictures/bag-o-beer588915.html

Bottle- Export Version. Pours like every other Asian pale lager. High carbonation. Slight hoppy bitterness. Body is light and metallic. Aftertaste is cardboard. Very watery overall. If there is one beer world mantra it is: green bottle = bad. Except for Pilsner Urquell.
Bottle. Smells skunky so maybe I got a ""bad"" one.  About the best thing I can say about this is it doesn’t taste that bad and doesn’t have an aftertaste.
(Bottle).  Slight hoppy aroma.  Pale golden body, disappearing head.  Not much flavor at all, watery, bland, pretty terrible.
Light yellow beer. The falvour and aroma are quite hard to describe, as they are very subtle at most. Slight notes of malt and metallic hops and quite strong notes of water. Yawn!
Bottle. Pours light golden with short-living head and no lacing. Qiute weak on the nose, of faint malt and hops. And weak and watery on the palate too. Not great.

bottle, label does not match the picture at all, but the imported beer claimed to be a tsingtao beer acc. to my notes. i probably spelled tsingtao wrong, as no tsingtao beer exists..  sampled at a chinese restaurant in alcudia spain.

aroma-mainly hoppy, sweet notes behind that.
appearance-yellow , thick white head.
flavor-not very strong flavor. sweet faint hops, sawdusty sweet notes. even though very weak, it is nicely balanced.
Pours golden with a small white head.  Aroma is light and of pale malts and a tiny bit of hops.  Flavor is pale malt with a small amount of hop crispness.  Not that bad.

12oz bottle: A hint of amber with a white fizzy head, pretty much looked like water, aroma might have a hint of malt, flavor slightly malty with a hint of lead. this beer is like a student turning in a test in a class with only half the problems done, all the other big lagers out there may not taste great but they do have taste.
bottle. had a skunky smell but taste wasnt all that bad. probably wouldnt try it again though.
Kind of skunky, light, watery, pale, forgettable.  Blame the green bottle I guess.
Bad news.  Smells and tastes like grass clippings thrown up from my rottweiler.  No hops, malt, head or lacing.  Generic ginger ale look without the bubbles.  Run away from this one.

"The finest beer from China." Let’s see how this goes. Pours the typical straw color with rapidly disappearing head of a typical American macro. Smells of something not hops or malt. Maybe corn/rice? Reminds me of the Beast. That smell magnifies when you drink it and it actually has a watery aftertaste. I never thought that would be possible. Coors Light and MGD slap this thing silly. Save your $1 and don’t buy it.
Yellow to clear, light, white thin head, only slightly hoppy in aroma and flavor, slight hint of sweetness and malt, a nice balance, refreshing, a bit lacking in complexity and flavor for me.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Specially bought this one for the Olympic Games, but i hope their are better Chinese beers than this one.

A watery, uninteresting beer, with  thin to non existant head. I would say it  is only good for washing down the dust and grime you will feel in your throat after walking a day in one of Chinas poluted cities.
Huge green bottle, aroma is malty and sweet, a little bit grassy taste, good for refreshing in a sunny day.
hops dominate on nose, hoppy on palate with some malt back-bone, nice finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear, very pale yellow with a thin white head.  Nose was skunky!  Ugh!  Why do they think a beer coming all the way from China would survive in green bottles?  Stupid.  Taste wasn’t horrible, but was definitely weak.  Some grass and yeast, but definitely not something I can tolerate.  Drain pour!
bottle, see through yellow color, burnt malty nose, head is large egg whites, sour malty flavor with a hoppy finish

Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a thin white head.  Taste is of malt, kind of sweet with a slightly bitter finish.  Aroma is much the same.  Pretty easy to drink and kind of refreshing.  Pairs well with certain foods.  Overall, this is a decent beer, but it is overpriced and kind of forgettable.

While not a great beer, Tsingtao is definitely serviceable. Best drunk out of a bottle or poured into a beer glass, avoid the larger versions. Tsingtao is not the bottom of the barrel, but it does elevate itself slightly above the crowd of awful beers below it.
Pours like apple cider from the bottle with a trim white head that quickly dissapates.  Smells like a homeless person, yet offers balanced flavors of red apples and yeast in the taste.

Aroma is malty and sweet, maybe some grass in there.  The appearance is a dark yellow with an orange tinge, a dark color for this style.  The flavor is malty and sweet, true to this style, but has a grassy and even spicy quality to it.  This mujst be from the hops they use, or they adjuncts they put into it.  No much hoppiness on the finish, more spicyness, and grass flavor.  Different.  Drinkable.

well what better time to rate a beer from china.pours white to very pale and i mean pale yellow very thin head aromas are faint but a skunk funk comes over in this beerthe taste is light like they just had a glass of water and added a hop tea bag hold on while  I spit this back in the glass this by far is the worst beer i have ever had a drain pour if i could give it a zero i would

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a very clear and very pale beer, with a white head. The aroma is full of rice and a little malt. The flavor is pilsnermalt, with a slightly yeasty sweetness and a mild ending. The palate is refreshing. Overall not a big tasting experience, but a refreshing lager beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a crystal clear thin, pale yellow color with a not so substantial head.  There is a complete lack of head retention.  Nose has a bit of skunkiness going on but passed that there is hints of grain and a touch of DMS.  There is a bit of skunk to start and then mostly light malt flavor with a slight bitterness at the end.  Very light bodied and easy to drink.  My opinion: just another mass produced American Lager that doesn’t really stand out from the crowd.
Very crisp, very dry. Standard lager taste. Goes well with Chinese food. Pale straw color with high carbonation.
A pretty boring lager, the Chinese did not do much but add a bit of rice flavor to spice it up. mostly tastes and feels like water.
Bottle @ Chinese restaurant. Sweet lager, rice taste, slightly hoppy finish. OK.

I like this one more than I thought I would. Tasted perfect with the spicy Vietnamese cuisine at the restaurant. It has all the normal lager characteristics, but it is a lot more sweet than the typical lager. Interesting.
gold blond coloured sparkling body with a white head a hoppy mout wallnuts aroma a sweet wattery hoppy wallnuts taste with a sweet bitter finish
Decent aroma, very weak and poor taste. It wasn’t watery it just didn’t have alot of flavor. Pretty crisp but there just wasn’t much to it.

Bottle and tap. Bottle is my favorite. Golden body. Aroma is classic lager yeast and sweet corn notes. Flavour is as expected, slightly sweet with some corn notes. Asked a chinese guy at Sanlitun, Beijing what TSINGTHAO means, and he reply was: "This Shit Is No Good, Try Another One". But it is not that bad i think.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a golden color with a light white head.  Lots of carbonation.  Combination of malts and corn flavors, perhaps even little rice.  Light bodied, about what I expected.  It pleasantly compliments the heat of Vietnamese food.

A few of these complimented my meal at Joe’s Ginger in Chinatown NYC......another light lager with little distinguishable character.....tasty and refreshing.....a solid liquid to wash down the bold flavours of Chinese cooking.....it also worked to help remove the stains from an exploding dumpling from my brother’s attire.......just OK.

Clear golden blond coloured beer with small white head and medium carbonation. Sweet (nuts) aroma. Full slightly creamy palate. Finish is first little bitter later you taste walnuts. Quite longer finish. Special one, I appreciated it very much. Keep the nuts coming.

I liked this beer and think most of the comments for this beer is tainted by personal issues these people have with Chinese people and not the beer.  

Good taste with a pleasant after taste.
Bottle. Pours golden yellow with a fizzy white head. Grainy aroma, a bit of hay. Light body. Lightly sweet malt profile, just a hint of floraly hops. Drinkable.

12oz Bottle My first and last China beer. i don’t buy stuff from China any way. But I had to kill my China rate. I guess I learned my lesson the hard way. This brew was skunk juice mixed with dirty China water.

If you like German pilsner’s, this isn’t a bad try. To me it tasted exactly like Warsteiner. Not as bad as I expected and definitely drinkable, it’s just sort of weird that most of the Asian countries have adopted German pilsners as their representative beers.
Good with a chinese meal, good wash-down.  Fairly watery.  Good bit carbonated too.

Presentation: It was poured from a green 12oz. bottle into a pint glass. It has a very pale straw color that is very clear with lots of visible carbonation. The head is thin, white in color and fades out quickly leaving no lace behind. Its aroma has big floral nose with light grainy malts along with a light skunky smell. Despite the skunk in the aroma the flavor is very clean with mild floral and delicate grainy sweetness followed by a mild bitterness in the finish. It has an easy drinking light body with just enough fizzy carbonation to give it some life. Overall it’s a very easy drinking lager with a modest light flavor. Average.
Pours bright gold into a snifter. Bright white head recedes to skim surface and hug rim.  Skunk aromas.  Crisp and slightly sweet upfront with a sour finish. Doesn’t taste as bad as it smells...
Decent Chinese mass produced beer. Tsingtao means clear island FWIW. solid beer.

Caramel and hay nose.  Frothy decent head, lemon gold color.  Light malt flavor and mild bitterness, soft and balanced.  Bubbly, lightish body, finishes slightly sweet but crisp.   Very refreshing and easy lager.

It pours out a rather typical straw yellow, not impressive, but the white head is thick and fluffy and hangs around for a bit. Aroma is crisp and malty, typical for a lager. Flavor is malty with a surprising hint of fruit, making it better than most macro-brew lagers. Texture is smooth and pleasant. Not outstanding, but OK, good as a companion to a meal.

Bottle hundreds of times.

Water and locally mass produced hops.  If in China go to this.  It reliable and sits well with spicy western chinese cuisine if your in Hunan or there abouts.  Why  do they import this stuff to the US though?

Very light on everything. Small head, no lacing. Slightest of hops aromas. Hops, malt and rice flavors, but barely detectable. Decent carbonation. Good beer for a Chinese meal when you’re concentrating on the food.
Bottled. Pours honey colored with a small white head. Aroma is brown rice and perhaps some burnt toast. Flavor is sweet grain. Thin but sweet body with at least some noticable malt.

330 ml bottle. Very pale yellow colour, thin white head. Mild aroma of malts, rice and some hops. Very thin and watery mouthfeel, weak carbonation. Thin flavour of malts and rice, tastes mostly like water. Don’t waste your time and money on this one.

Appearance: Pale yellow. Little head. Fizzy.
Aroma: Hopsy (very). Normal lager.
Taste: Hopsy, fresh. No malt. Standard light lager.
Info: 330ml bottle, 23/3-2006, 54/500

Bottle.  Golden pour with a white head.  Faint aroma of stale hops, flavor has a decent malt base with a strange balancing bitterness.  I dont know whats premium about this, just like any other pale lager.  Apparently there are no adjuncts... so I guess the Chinese will put rice in everything except beer.
I hope China has  much better beers to offer. This is one of or the only Chinese beer I have ever had and it just isn’t very good. Would not buy again
bottle from Citymarket Sello (nice selection by the way) Golden with white head. sweet honey. exactly light but tasty like a mediterranean beer. (almaza for example)
Close.  I would have given it a 7.  Aroma is of stale malt and skunky hops.  Not a good beer.  wouldn’t buy again
Stray bottle from LCBO. Straw yellow with no head and low carb. Light florals and grains in aroma. Staw/hay-like  flavour. Thin mouth feel. Bland.
Despite what the commercial description says... I can’t taste or smell any hops. A little malt. Not even close to a good lager.
Bottle at Chinese restaurant in Bayswater London. Clear pale yellow colour with large creamy white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma. Sweet flavor.
This basically tasted like a Chinese Bud Light. If this beer isn’t so cold, you can’t taste the flavor, it’s not worth drinking. Tastes like water.

bottle.  Aroma of honey, malt and macro lager.  Pale golden hue with average white head that fully diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is honey hops and macro lager.  Palate is light and lively.  Not bad and better than most American brews but still crap.

Pale golden color with thin white head.  Mild cereal grain aroma with hints of wet hay and citrus.  Thin bodied with light mouthfeel, plenty of effervesence.  Light sweet malt taste with gentle, crisp, somewhat dry hop finish.  Very refreshing, great session beer.
Bottle. Pours golden yellow with a little white head. Aroma is corn and light hops. Flavor much of the same. Pretty sharp mouthfeel served very cold. Not good, but definately refreshing.
Bottle. Pours clear gold with a off white head. Mild malts - hay/grass with a medium & short bitterness. Watery . . bland!

Drank quite a bit of this in Shanghai and Hong Kong and it wasn’t bad at all.  Crisp, clean flavor with mild hops and some malts.  Body is a bit thin, but that actually adds to its drinkability.  Was incredibly fresh.  I imagine it’s not nearly as good outside of China due to the green bottle, but if you can find it fresh it’s a pretty respectable macro lager.
Nothing terrible about this beer, just nothing outstanding.  Clean like Heineken without the bite on the finish.  Other than that, nothing to write home about.

Bottle.  Poured light golden colour with a thick fast dssapearing head.  Aroma of grain, and adjunct.  Flat watery flavour, not much like beer.  Flat finish.

This isn’t a drain pour because it does have some thirst quenching properties, and I drank it after hard labour in the yard.
lighter golden colour, the aroma is weak and faint of grain, and maybe a little corn. a watery finish, and for the most part hardly any distinct flavors at all.
El origen del nombre de esta cerveza data de la epoca de mao y su traduccion a nuestra lengua es chingao.  Es de conocimiento publico q mao tenia a todo su pueblo chingao
Basically China’s Heineken, which isn’t saying much. Nothing excting here. Little to no flavor, with the exception of a little skunkiness, perhaps due to the green bottle. A passer overall.
A light lager with not much going on. The rice makes it very fresh and drinkable though. I wan’t impressed by the aroma, while the beer itself were nice on a warm day...

12 oz bottle. Poured light golden color with thin white head. Little lacing. Aroma was slightly skunky, but detected sweet notes as well as some hops aroma. Taste was better than expected, slightly sweet and bitter. Kind of reminded me of a pilsner. Palate was somewhat thin however
Clear golden with large white head. Sweet grainy aroma with vegetable notes. Sweet flavor with cardboard notes. Ends slightly bitter.
yellow pour with no head just some bubbles on top.  very skunky, malty smell.  good thickness and would go nice with a spicy meal quite well.
Not so good, but not the worst either.  Another in a long line of typical Asian style beers.  Must be ice cold!!
330 ml green bottle. golden colour. small white, quickely disapearing head. taste is okay, bit grainy.
22 oz bottle from Country Club Liquors; pale gold, medium white head; nose not grainy, just some faint caramel notesflavor has some sweetness, light caramel, and a little pepperiness.

Had this in the bottle at Bottlescrew Bill’s. This beer is pretty bad. Tinny soapy taste and a gross feeling in your mouth. I don’t recommend this to anyone. It looks like a normal beer though, so I guess it’s got that going for you. I’m not gonna rate the appearance any higher than the default because I don’t think this beer deserves over 1 as a total score. It’s that bad.
(Bottle on 2008-01-13) Very pale and clear, some white head. Has got almost no taste.

Bottle. Had this with a serving of Peking Duck at my favorite sit down Chinese place. Their beer list was lacking, so I threw caution to the wind and ordered one. It’s not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, but its not all that great either. MIddle of the road lager beer. No better or worse than a Bud.
Mildly skunky and pissy smell. Yellow with a medium head. Tastes like watered down urine. Lacks any redeeming value except for the fact that it is only mildly offensive.
From a bottle poured clear golden color with a small head.  Decent flavor, kind of watery with no real finish.

Bottle.  Poured a clear golden color with a thin, fizzy white head.  Aroma of light pilsner malt and grass.  Light maltiness leads into a pretty watery finish.  Not much flavor, reminds me of Heineken in a way.  Alright with Chinese food, but that’s only if they don’t have anything else.

Bottle. Very grassy and hoppy, moderate sour. Small white foamy head, fast and fully diminishing, clear yellow body. Light sweet start, then it gets even sweeter; very short duration. Light body, light dry and watery, soft carbonation. Not my cup of tea...
Pale yellow with thin white head.  Aroma of corn and sweet malts.  Next to no flavor, some corn and whatnot, but yet another mass-produced lager that is way too abundant in the world.

The pour is a lighter golden yellow.  With a small ring white suds that was supposed to be the head.  The aroma is very light/subtle...a hint of grassy hops, mellow malts.  The beer is very light bodied, the hops from the aroma fail to make an appearance on the pallate, and the malts are still very light...This beer is probably best drunk in the heat of the summer.
Despite it being rather gassy I did enjoy this beer while in China. It was extremely cheap and I thought it was one of the better Asian brewed beers I’ve had.

...well, not much here, other than rice, and cleansing qualities for spicy asian food.  Highly carbonated, with a slight yeast malt taste, but not really.  Pretty much avoid this unless your name is Wang, Chang, or Yi.
I love Chinese food, but this beer is not good at all. It’s only good to wash down food. No taste.
Not good at all. I just had this to post a Chinese rating. Bitter, harsh, highly carbonated.

Pours pale clear yellow,  Large medium-dense white foam head. Just a little bubbling. Aroma is good a skunky at first like a nice pilsenser, but then closer inspection reveals sharp corn malt to the nose. Tastes like sweet sugar water with trace amounts of malt and hops mixed in maybe somewhere, but hard to detect.. Palate is a little tingly. Finish is a little harsh. Tastes much better in shenzhen.

Was the only option I had in a Chinese restaurant once and I actually liked it. Maybe it was because I thought I’d hate it, but it wasn’t bad. I’d certainly get it again, but not something I’d go looking for. I’ve hear of it being skunky.
Yellow color and clear with a thin head.  Off smell with a little hops and a touch of malts.  Taste is weak, water with malts like tea.

Pours a nice golden color there is nothing spectacular about this beer but it is a solid easy drinking beer ... if it was american it would hang with yuengling bud miller coors on the shelf a safe one
into pint, had at a chinese restaurant.  Was not bad, better than most macros, and went well with the food, served its purpose as a sessionable companion to the food.
12 ounce bottle-  prototypical lager, pours out clear yellow with a white head, heavy carbonation.  Pretty typical taste, kind of light to watery strong on malt, hops virtually absent.  Average.
Thin, malty, lively on the tongue with a weak attempt at bitterness in the finish.  Similar to a Budweiser.
12 oz bottle. Crisp and fairly refreshing in offensive beer. Sort of a soda with some alcohol in it. It goes okay with chinese food I guess. Not filling, not flavorful, not much of anything.

For what it is, it’s not bad. Pours a really pale straw color with a small white head.  Not much aroma.  Fairly balanced malt with light hop finish.  Not much to it, but it’s ok--goes pretty well with some sushi.
Pale gold body and thin white head. hoppy aroma with grass. little bitter in the finish. not very intersting.
Bottle. First tried this one at the ’82 world’s fair. Wasn’t that bad. Recently tried it again. Whew! skunk beer. Tastes like skunk water. Sure did change. Won’t try it again. Do not recommend.
Straw color with a medium white head that vanishes quickly. Smells skunky with a bit of hops and grass. taste is weak and slightly watery
12 oz bottle pours a clear golden with a thin white head.  Aroma is of some hops and a little skunky. Flavor is of slight hop bitterness and a little grainy malt.

Bottle from Cost Plus. Pours a light golden color with thin white head. Nose has a bit of hops and grassy overtones.  A bit skunky.  Palate is slightly sweet with just a bit of hops bitterness and a slight skunky aftertaste.  This is a yardwork beer.  You could slam a few of these after coming in sweaty from mowing the lawn.
I had quite a few of these in Shanghai and Beijing, but I actually found this one at my local brew store.  Brought back thoughts of good times w/ my best friend.  Awesome... I need more.

I used to just drink this beer right from the bottle.  Today, I poured into a frosty pint glass.  Surprise!  Very clear and light in color.  Aroma similar to Heineken but not as strong in flavor.  A nice and clean lager from start to finish.  Goes great with Chinese food...especially a good hot and sour soup.
Not bad at all for a macro-beer.  Not much of a head.  Aroma has a neutralness.  The taste is not too memorable but I did enjoy its smoothness.

Nothing about this impressed me.  I guess I should have expected it, considering it’s a lager made in China.  I guess the novelty couldn’t put something of quality into my bottle.  Very average.  It could have said beer on the side.  It’s beer at best, and not good beer.
Bottle, dont know what to say to this beer, it has no head, very light. Boring, in asia they still need to learn make beer.
Pours clear with a slight amber color and a very white foamy head. Malty grassy aroma. Taste is clean and crisp with some malty hints. Not my favorite, but not terrible.

I can’t believe I used to "like" this beer. Very very odd. Pours a crystal clear yellow with a small ring of white foam around the top. Aroma of apple cider, which, funnily enough, is exactly how it tastes. I don’t know if it was my batch/bottle/glass but I could swear it tasted like a cider/beer hybrid. Very odd. Undercarbonated and thin. Some notes of alcohol. No aftertaste. Done and done.

well, 12 ounce bottle from Oliver’s beverage. Green bottle which is their first mistake. Pours very light, no head, skunky. Im pretty well convinced that Milwaukees best has a plant in China and they bottle under this name. Please, find anything else if it is available.
definately skunky and overexposed! This beer is not something I would wish on anyone. the aroma and taste is almost nonexhistent. perhaps it better overseas, I hope so.

If you can find a bottle that hasn’t been blasted to death by fluorescent light then it is actually quite good. Nothing memorable but all in all a pretty refreshing beer. Standard lager here, which isn’t a bad thing.

It seems about half of their product gets skunky before it reaches the consumer though, so beware!
No head, skunky nose and taste with a bitter acid finish. It was plain. Its not really even drinkable.

Blah. Had this at my birthday party with sushi and even that couldn’t mask the horrible-ness of this beer. Aroma was a weak mix of light malt and corn. Pour was a light bubbly gold with a 2 finger white head. Taste was full of adjunct. Corn or rice maybe? A light malt sweet aftertaste that didn’t help much.
While better then some of the lesser American macro-brews, Tsingtao is not a memorable beer. Bad aroma is forgiven by a watered down taste. Not a beer that you must try.

Bottle. Pours a light golden color with a small white head. Light aroma of ginger and grain. The taste is much of the same a tangy gingery bite, a slight hint of hops, and some grainy flavor. I’ve enjoyed this beer over the years for its nice flavor that is unique to it’s self.
Really light and grainy on the palate, virtually no aroma, watery in appearance, lacking on all fronts really.

Clean fairly fresh aroma, not really hoppy but more interesting than most "premium lager". Flavor is somewhat grainy and a hint of earthy hops. Finish is more of the same. Very clean. I was gifted a 6 pack of this and I’m already halfway through. I think it’s underrated here, but let’s not be mistaken, it’s nothing mindblowing.
This beer was nothing special.  Its the bud light of China basically, but slightly better I guess.
it one of the worst ive tasted, i will never drink it again, try it on your own risk
12 bottle. pretty metallic skunky aroma. yellow and boring. lacking any interesting flavor or personality. it pretty much sucks. will never buy it again. better than MGD Urine Lager, but not by much.

Very disappointing. I had heard decent things about this beer but at first open it smelled skunky. Taste was not as bad as the smell but you could tell it was either not fresh or was just a poor beer. Bad way to kick off the night.

Nice clean aroma, not too sure about the purported hoppiness though. The length of the journey probably doesn’t help. The flavour is initially soft, balanced and surprisingly fresh but develops an unpleasant industrial edge at the finish, probably due to the use of rice. Thin body. Ok for a light lager, but considering the air miles to quality ratio, I don’t see why people would drink this beer.
drinkable, crisp, light beer with a straw gold appearance and a thin, fizzy white head. clean but lacking the sophistication and complexity of other lagers

[829-20071108] 330mL. Aroma has a bit of metallic plasticky fish, a bit of straw, and a bit of sweet honey in the background. Clear, dark yellow body with a quick bubbly white head. Flavour has a sweet hint of light honey straw malt. Light-medium body has a little astringency. Would go well with seafood; nice sweet finish makes up for the smell... almost. (I like how they kept the old spelling for the beer name even though its namesake city had to change with the new conventions.)

[i]Bottle (33 cl) from Systembolaget, Munkebäck, Göteborg, Sweden[/i]. Pale golden with a medium fizzy head. Contains rice according to the label, and there is some kind of oily, pear-ish, sake-like maltiness to it. Light in body with spritzy carbonation. A bit sweet with a tiny bitter touch in the finish. Not good, but decent.
Nice and light with a crisp clean after taste. Looks like a crappy beer but the taste is worth the beer. Definitly trying to drink it at Peeking!
(Bottle) Pours a yellow color with a small, fizzy head. Aroma of corn and light hops. Taste includes light sweet malts, corn and light hops. High carbonation. Not particularly good.

This beer was so bad, I had not rate it here at the site, after not having rated for a while.  Thick white head, little color maybe yellow, unmistakenly smelled like skunk, some carbonation.  Tasted like water with a splash of armpit.

skunky, brown, clear, aminimal head, brown foam, medium bitterness, vinegar, light body, thin feel, fizzy, bitter.
Disappointed by size of head and how fast it disappeared. The second thing I noticed was the smell was very unpleasant. The smell made it difficult to want to drink the beer. The look very watery. This beer is not appealing at all.

Shows its German heritage (brewery originally established by German colonial masters; most brewmasters still alumni of famed Munich Technical University’s Weihenstephan Institute as are many of their peers around the world).
