chinese miller... pours a light pea yellow.. w/ a small head.. smells like stale rotten eggs and malt.. paalte is overly carbonated water.. flavor is lightly malty lightly hoppy and some stale cardboard... this stuff is not good.

Very pale yellow hue, shy foamy head, skunky smell at the opening of the bottle, pale malt, mild floral accent, maybe hint of vanilla in the nose, follows through on a light-medium bodied palate, with crisp pale malt, touch of soft maltiness, in  very light hoppy finish.

Bottle at Chan’s. And you know what they say...when in rome...Pale yellow, white head that fades. Frat house beer aroma with a cooked corn DMS note. Thin and lifeless pale malts with little hops. Distinct note of Formaldehyde. ;-)

If they don’t have water, ask for this. It’s about the same thing. It’s the same color yellow as the Oregon Ducks jerseys, it has a big fizzy head, and it’s so carbonated that it makes me think of the prank from Animal House where they fill the swimming pool with fizzies.
Pale yellow, quickly deminishing head, no lace. No aroma. Neutral palate. "Refreshing" only in a macro-brewed pale lager sense. Absolutely nothing unique here.

Bottle: Poured a golden color lager with a small bubbly white head with minimal retention. Aroma of weak malt and hops with bad case of skunk in the back. Taste is pretty inoffensive apart from the bad case of skunkyness. You have to wondered why they import all those crappy lager into North Amercia…

Old review (German Export 5% version):
Ooh, my first Chinese beer. Pours a medium sized and thick white head. Surprise, surprise, it was pale and yellow. Bad malt nose, comparable to a n/a nose. Oh, and my Tsingtao (German export, but found in the Scout Club Irish Pub in Samobor) had 5% alc.. The taste was cardboardy, but the lemon dominated. Why on earth is this imported here ? (3/2/4/1/8)

pours goldenish in color with a small white head, smell is mostly of malts, a tiny bit of skukiness in the aroma, taste was slightly sweet with a slight bitter finish, ok body a little watery, not a bad beer, it drinkable .

Out of a bottle, it’s light, a little cloudy, quickly dispersing head.  Aromas of grains, similar to American macro brews.  The taste is nothing to write home about.  Watery, but not bad.  Goes very well (as it should) with Asian cuisine.
Very pleasing to the palate especiialy when paired with Chinese food (that is being consumed in huge quantities).  Very light in color.  Much subtler than the Pale Ales that I am used to.
(bottle)  Poured golden yellow.  Yeast and hops apparent.  Surprisingly, I really enjoyed this beer.
It’s the most common beer in chinese restaurants here in Greece. If well chilled then it’s ok.
Bottle 12oz. Clear light amber with small white head. Small aroma. Light body with small texture. Light flavor with little to no finish. Clearly a below average lager.

My wife said the aroma wafts of skunk piss and malt, whatever that means.  Nice golden color, decent pils pour.  Unlike some of the other comments I found this to be an all over satisfying brew on par with a Heiniken or a Becks, but with a lighter swallow.  Overall I would pick this up again.

(bottle) Clear yellow/straw colour with a medium frothy white head. Weak malty aroma, slightly skunky. Sweetish flavour, medium body, somewhat crispy mouthfeel. Starts a bit sweetmalty turning into a low and short hoppy, slightly perfumed finish. This one is not that bad and I can imagine to have it with tasty/spicy (southern) chinese food, but I would prefer a sweet Riesling wine with a well-balanced sweetness-acidity proportion from Germany or Austria….and believe me or not: my best friend I had in the Kindergarten near Frankfurt/Main (greetings to Udo Krick !)  is one of  the grandsons of the founder of the brewery during Germanys former colonial times.

Bottle. Smells slightly sour and tastes the same. Light hoppy presence (slight bitterness) but nothing to rave about. Quite watery with little aftertaste. I wasn’t expecting much, but it’s tastier then some of the cheap domestics I’ve had. I wanted to try a chinese beer and I guess I’ll be looking for something different to try.
Out of a can with an old fashioned pull off ring pull...it almost explodes when opened. As far as Asian beers are concerned, run of the mill

I was gonna wait ti I went to a Chinese restaurant, but it was on sale. As far as generic country lagers go, this is definitely at or near the top of my list. Good slightly warm too, great for what it is.
An ok beer from China.  I think this will be my first beer from that part of the world.  Similar to Japanese beers I guess.  I can’t tell the beers apart.  Skunky smell, but taste is fine.
Very pale yellow with big dissapearing offwhite head. Aroma is a bit weak with some sweetness and a bitter hint. Taste is sweet with sweet aftertaste and only a notes of bitterness.
Bottle. Pale yellow with hardly any head. This beer has aromas of skunk, tin cans and flowers, and an insipidly bland rice cracker taste. Okay with spicy Chinese food, but that’s about it.

12 oz bottle—1st 6 pack I got was an outdated batch, which I didn’t notice till I was having the 1st beer from it and not enjoying it too much.  The first one fit a number of descriptions I’ve read on this beer, like-skunky, not much different than the US macros, shipping conditions that the beer was subjected to, etc..  The store was kind enough to do a swap for a different 6 pack with a more recent bottling date.  So, that’s the 6 pack I will rate as there was a big difference between the 2.    Pours a mild yellow, pale golden color, white head that is quite high, reduced to about 1/2 “ and held for much of that beers existence.  Aroma is light and citrusy, lime possibly? Along with a sweetness, possibly corn.  Carbonation and taste are good, an enjoyable beer.

Surprise, I had it at a chinese all-you-can-eatery.  Pours light yellow amber, small head, and a slight aroma.  Very light taste, alittle better than Heiney.  You’d think a country that came up with Kung Pao would have a beer with a bit more pow.

Pours light yellow with a pretty large white head that settles to about 1/4 inch and laces the glass on the way down.  The aroma is kind of skunky.  Maybe a little malt and corn in there but the aroma is really not that strong on this one.  Tastes of sweet corn and maybe some rice come through in this one.  It has a somewhat sweet aftertaste that lingers some.  On the palate it is very carbonated yet somewhat watery and thin.  Reminded me very much of the standard American brews like budweiser.  Nothing worth picking up again by any means.

Aroma is mostly skunk, with some light malt and a fresh grassy kind of smell (not all that unpleasant).  The appearance is a bright, clear pale yellow.  Flavor is, like the aroma, mostly skunky, with some hints of malt and what seem to be good hops buried in there.  The palate was thin and watery, with high carbonation.  Overall this was a disappointment.  Definitely not worth the price, and not nearly as premium as it’s marketed as.  The elements for a crisp, refreshing brew are there, they’re just buried under the skunkiness and diluted in a thin, watery beer.  What a shame.

Pours a lasting white head over a pale straw beer.  Aroma of hay and malt.  Crisp and light.  A bit of hop character (Saaz?) that gives it a snap.  I think it is way better than US macros.  I think it’s skunkiness varies with it’s handling and age.  I’ve had some really fine ones and others that are really bad.

One of my SAT analogy questions went like this: Miller Lite is to Yanjing as Budweiser is to ______.  The correct answer was Tsingtao.   As Chinese beers go, this one is not bad.  It won’t stand to match any quality Western beer, but as the Chinese say, "ru xiang sui su" - do as the locals do, and in China, the locals really do enjoy this beer and regard it as China’s best.   It’s even said that if you drink enough of this beer, you’ll be able to speak Chinese.  Try it and see.

Standard Chinese restaurant brew. Pale yellow; thin, weak head, faint skunky aroma,  pretty much sume it up. A bit more muscle compared to the average American standard, but I would agree as previously mentioned, very "Heineken like." I’ll take it over a Bud or Miller, but just barely.

Drinkable is such a good word to describe this lager. Nothing amazing, but definatly drinkable. Thats not saying very much though... because technically gasoline is drinkable. Asian Delight? I think not!

Drinkable Chinese lager, better than some Asian contemporaries but not particularly satisfying. Straw colour, short vanishing head. Bit more aromatic hops than is typical for the region. Quenching palate. This at least has some bitterness. (Bottle)

I always thought this was the Chineese equivilant of Miller/Bud, but I have a few friends that said it was really good. I ordered one at a Thai restaurant, and I knew almost instantly that my inclinations were correct. Skunky, watery, and blah. I’m not a fan these kind of lagers, and this beer reinforces that.
Characteristics that you don’t want in a beer are present -- tin flavour, skunky, loads of corn flavour, high carbonation...  premium lager??  Oops.
Watered down lager. This must be the Budweiser of China. Even in America this stuff isn’t very expensive. Don’t bother. There are beers that taste the same (watery) and cost less...
Pour is a pale yellow with a small head.  Aroma is skunk with some sulfer in there.  Smells like a fireworks factory.  Flavor is typical lager.  Heineken like in more ways than one.
It is not as bad as i thought a skunk taste but taste liek a certain euro beer very poopular here. I would never buy again but not totally bad
Gold body, white foamy head. Smells of malt and rice. Very carbonated, rather bland taste. Only shows some skunked malts. Decent lager. Sampled in Beijing, China.
i expected the worst with this beer. and trust me it is terrible. it has a nasty skunk taste to it, but it still might be better than a milwaukee’s best. only by a little though. and i love the beast
Bottled. Pale golden/yellowish colour with small white bubbly head. Hoppy aroma along with skunkyness. Rich carbonation and flavour is sweet malt and hoppy with hints of maize.

Light yellow color, little white head. Mildly hoppy aroma, some sweet and skunky tones too. Flavor has grassy notes with lasting hops and carbonation. Dry ending with somehow oily palate. Thin to medium bodied.
Pours a golden yellow color with a nice white head.  Aroma is skunky.  Flavor is a little hoppy and kind of weak.
Yellow/gold color. Skunky aroma, with some hops as well. Flavor is mostly sweet malt hops, and corn.

It is not fair to abuse this beer wholesale: we do not expect good beers from China.  Yet we must be fair and honest, for the sake of good beers.
Perhaps the ugliest pale dead-grass milky straw pour ever.  Aroma slightly offensive raccoon musk.  Flavor of raccoon meat, undercooked and left in the sun.  Mouthfeel is meay and overcarbonated, with greasy toothvarnish.  However, this beer did not kill me, and if I had been eating powerfuly spiced or flavored foods, would not have been too averse to its light nothingness.
this is pretty expensive for a beer this crappy, in the us anyway.  it’s sad to think that this is china’s most famous beer.
Only beer availible in a chinese resturant. a good thirst quencher, smooth.  Closer to something brewed in North America, then China. An ok lager
To my tastebuds, this is a slightly more flavorful, hopsier Budweiser.  The novelty of drinking a Chinese beer wore off pretty quick.

I dunno who classified this as a premium lager because it certainly isn’t premium.  There are a lot worse beers out there, it was kind of light and refreshing without any huge flavour.  A bit on the dull side and not much head.  It isn’t going to knock your socks off, but its probably a lot better than most Chinese beers.

Much compact foam and creamy one; optimal persistence. Discreet scent but without pretensions, to read notes of malt and grass. Much limpid and diamond, persistent bubbly. Fresh and light taste. Balanced with a determined bitter. Unexpected.

This was the first and last time I will try this beer. Sampled from a 12 oz green bottle this beer poured a straw yellow color with a small soapy white head. The aroma was sour and skunky. The flavor was sour malt, skunk, and a bit corny. The mouthfeel was surprisingly thick which was the only redeeming quality I could find. Drain pour. ANY BREWER WHO CONSENTS TO PUTTING THE BEER IN A GREEN BOTTLE SHOULD BE BANNED FROM EVER BREWING AGAIN!!!!!!!!!!!!!
A lager like any other for the most part.  Light tasting, only with a touch of bitterness at the finish.
Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of bread, toast and skunk.  Flavor is sweet with a little tangy bitterness.
Although it is slightly bitter, and I like bitter, this is a fairly watery brew with little to recommed it.  It would be inoffensive with dinner in a chinese restaurant.

frosted lager glass / surprisingly not that bad. i had it with my dinner at an asian restaurant called Aloha, in Decatur, IL. i prefer the food. there were actually some flavor, but i’m not remembering what it was; otherwise, it’s a bit sweet, and it’s active. rice? anyway...  i’m guessing this would be cloying and anything that is far away from drinkable, if let to warm. drink it cold, and use it to wash down your food.
My friend bought a bottle of this at papago. Poured some in a glass for me. Well a bitter beer that maybe to me it’s only purpose besides the free tee shirt is another rating.
A very average lager.  Well Balanced, very smooth.  Very American in flavor.

This stuff was awful. Terrible bitter taste, no head, just kind of sat there in the glass not doing anything.  After I swallowed it, it just kind of sat there in my gut waiting to be expelled.  Which I did in due time.

My first ever Chinese beer.  Maybe my last.  It had no smell, no flavor, no mouthfeel, and a barely discernible hop bitter.  If you’re ever having a party and you run out of water, just break out the Tsingtao.

This beer claims to be made with spring water from Laoshan, which is ancient chinese for "my basement bathroom’s toilet tank".  This only served to cleanse my palate of all taste before moving on to a real man’s beer.  I then crushed the bottle with the cleft of my chin and ate the shards just to toughen up my stomach more, while laughing like a pirate who has just pillaged and sunk a Spanish Galleon

Bottle: Quite surprised by this really. With typical pale gold hues and a scummy white head this looked like a standard pale lager. However, the saazy like aroma with soem enticing citrussy notes suggested otherwise. The flavour was somewhat left-field with some faint malts as a structural base upon which sweet citrussy tones were layered, turning into tropical fruit towards the end. Smooth and refreshing, the only real faults of this beer is that it isn’t particularly flavourful and that after half a glass one was left with a slightly sour aftertaste. Quite reasonable.

Only beer i see here in the states from China. A watered down gold body and foam head that stays a fluff for few seconds. This is a actual pleasant beer and its pretty good or maybe because im eating Chinese take out with it.  It certainly isn’t anything worth buying again but at least i know its not that bad.

Bright gold with white bubbly head that lasts for a little while until it recedes into a thin cover.  Some pleasant noble hops and some malt to balance it with only a touch of pepe le pieu.  Very little flavour that contains some hops and, unexpectedly, raisin and grain.  No bitterness to speak of.  Light body and good carbonation level.
Boring,bland, and so many better choices abound for this cuisine.  But if that’s the only import they offer, I’ll have one or four...
Pretty much the Budweiser of China. Light Yellow pour with rapidly declining head. Palate is weak. Not bad overall, but not great.

The best way to describe this one is Bush beer with a Chinese label.  I’ve been experimenting with various Asian beers lately for a party I’m throwing and definitely will not be offering this one to my guests.  Nothing special here.
Cheap yellow gold color with a white head and little to no lacing.  Ceral grains in aroma and taste.  Slight grassy hops.  Weak palate.  Not offensive...just a mild summery brew.

Nothing special here.Decent golden color,small head that faded quickly leaving little behind.The aroma was maybe a light malt with a bit of a sweet side and a hint of hops.The flavor was decent light malty side some mild bitterness and mild hop showing.Over all it finished up fairly clean with a thin feel.Not bad but definately could be better.

Has an acidic somewhat metallic taste. While it has a somewhat pleasant aroma it has only a light malty taste and a cheap soapy hops. The only things this beer is good with is strong food because it will compete with the flavor maybe even cover up a bad food taste.

Only with Chinese food please, though still more distinctive than any American macro.  Sweet, with unique, if not entirely pleasant, metallic flavor.  Seriously, you would never drink this outside of your local Chinse restaurant.
Sweet flavour.  Flavor similar to macro-brewed lager, with more Palate.  Dryish aftertaste.  Brilliant gold pour with clear white boutiful head.
355ml green bottle. Poured gold, white head dissipates quickly, leaves slight ring in glass. Sweetish malts, some hops in finish. Light and dryish.

Bouteille verte de 355 ml. Arôme: Très légèrement "skunké". Odeur de houblon assez présente. Apparence: Couleur paille. Petit col qui disparaît vite. Faible carbonisation. Saveur: Très léger goût de moufette. Goût de houblon prononcé. Palette: Légère amertume agréable en bouche. (Rating #19)
Poured lemon colour with a short white head. Aroma of boiled veges. Typical sweet corn adjunct flavour. Thin watery feel. Quite refreshing, be fine in the heat, but not my cup of tea i’m afraid.
bitter light lager. goes well with food. very hoppy taste that remains consistent throughout. umm, tastes like a lot of other asian beers.

A descent beer. Its got some hops which certainly helps out a flavor. Would most definitly take this over any of the cheaper american macros. Very refreshing and wouldnt complain drinkin this when offered.

Surprisingly, I did not think that this Chinese beer was as negative as the reviews indicate.  The flavor was not all that bitter, providing a smooth and crisp tasting lager.  Lacking any definitive beer taste though, relatively poor in that respect.  For a light tasting option though, not that bad.
Although it’s a must when eating Chineese, the beer’s not very good standing on its own.  Fizzy, golden and an improper balance of hops to malt.  This one’s more for novelty sake.
Okay, you don’t make beer and I won’t try to make Chinese food.  Sound like a deal?
This is a real lager, good taste, goes down really smooth, only thing is it’s kinda pricey but definitely something to get once in a while when i want a good lager.
Light color, and not much of an aroma. Has a week taste. Nothing special about it, just bland.

golden yellow small head with a good  sweet aroma.
Bitter odd tasting beer well  Carbonated metalic finish.
A plain,watery beer, good with hot chinese food, but I’d rather have an MGD with my Chinese food. I think the Chinese will advance in brewing, and this beer will be left behind.
It’s clean... pale yellow... malty... good with chiles... but stand alone it’s just like perrier.  Carbonated watery and unsatisfying.
The white head diasapears quick. No hop. A beer with almost no taste. This beer is good when it is served in a chinese restaurant with a couple of friends.
White head that disappear fast, pale yellow body, not a bad taste but a little watery. A good beer to quench thirst and with a hot meal, but standalone it is not exceptional.

From a botte into a small lager glass: Straw-colored with a pretty "meringue" head.  Some  malt presence in the aroma, otherwise grainy.  Very smooth and not excessively carbonated.  No tastes really stand out (good or bad).  I’d better try another to check consistency.  Yup, second one looks, smells and tastes just like the first one did--good, but hardly exciting beer.

Beer pours pale golden, lots of carbonation and a well retained egg white head.  Aroma is grassy and skunky with a faint hop note in the background.  Flavor is sweet and bland and contains a hint of hop spiciness in the finish.  Blah.
Aroma?  Does it really have one? My nose didn’t get much off of it.  The appearance is a pale yellow.  Flavor is somewhat sweet, but generally bland.  The palate is inoffensive.  Not a great beer.
I had this at a Chinese restaurant with Chinese seafood. It was okay and went well with the food, but I didn’t think it was all that smooth.
Dark Yeollow --- corny, wheaty aroma --- decent carbonations --- corn with some malt taste --- went well with the Chinese buffet -
Bright tasting and gummy.  Nice golden color for a lager.  Can’t specify the metamorphizing taste, but it’s nice.  Hops too.  One from the ol’ PRC supplies the list, and I can’t say its a bad beer.

After the beer was served in the glass there was found a lasting quantity wall adhesive white foam collar which was fine and even of structure. The beer also contained much carbonic acid in the glass. The beer has a clear yellow color and a sweet taste. The after tast of the beer is hoppy bitter with a dusty touch . This beer smells to malty.
A nice golden coloring with strong carbonation, this offers a very mild malty aroma.  It’s a clean, crisp drink that goes good with any meal.

Actually better than I had hoped for. Poured pale yellow color with white fizzy head, typical beer/wheat aroma.  Some kind of rice/corn flavor that balances well with the maltiness.  Paired perfectly with a spicy dish of kung pao chicken

So pale and clear I thought it would explode.  No head, save a couple bubbles.  Skunked hops, grainy apple aroma. Thin with very little carbonation. Corn and cheap grainy flavour. Maybe some spice. Gritty hit and miss finish.
Not bad at all...pretty refreshing and reminds me a bit fo the Japanese beers.  Pretty tasty and thank goodness...this stuff gets passed around like water in Shanghai.
I must have got a really fresh bottle of this because it had a lot more maltiness than I expected.  Unspectacular, but easy drinking with enough flavour to make you want more than one.  Or two...

Chuckometer - 8 beers and its up.

Need to im prove label - let’s bring it into the modern economy. The ’Party’  should loosen the grip on it. It looks really communist.

I had low expectations, but was pleasently surprised. There is definitely something going on with the rice in there. Clean hoppy taste with light maltiness.  I was thirsty when I drank it so it barely touched the sides as it were.

(Bottled, 4.6% ABV) Very pale yellow color with medium, slightly lacy head. Quite clean, sweet, somewhat hoppy aroma with rice and corn. Grassy-hoppy, sweetish and corny flavor with little malt. Quite long, bitter finish. Clean, light-bodied, carbonated, quite refreshing palate. Not that bad for such a pale brew.

Green bottle, long journey, ’nuff said! 
Ok, ok.  Pale yellow lager with a small, fizzy, white head. A touch lightstruck, therefore, the aroma is a bit skunked. The flavor isn’t unpleasant, but has strong notes of corn.  Short, crisp, clean finish. Goes decently with raw fish, but probably wouldn’t stand up well on its own.
Clear yellow color, short head. Weak aroma of rice. Bit bitter taste, very watery.
Pours a pale yellow color. Kind of grainy and skunky in aroma. Has an artificially sweet grainy flavor. A little metallic.

Incredible, I have had so many of these and have not yet rated it. Unlike many others I actually don’t mind this. It is only to be consumed with Chinese food and preferably in their restaurants, not with take-away. I agree that it simetimes has a goss odour but often in Australia it is fresh and therefore not lightstruck. the most recent foray with this was last Saturday at the Sharkfin Restaurant in Melbourne’s Chinatown. After a day at the races where the stinky boys consumed about 10 Carlton Draughts followed by a couple of Belgians in our hotel room before the footy, this was not a bad drop. A more serious review may be less kind so let’s just leave it at that.

You’re in Chinatown in London and Tsingtao is absent on your personal ratebeer list, what do you do...? That’s right, you drink this crappy lager! Not even that bad btw, nice alternative after all these bitters.

Pours pale yellow with a thick foamy head that diminishes fairly rapidly.  Sweet corn or rice notes to the nose with mild hoppiness.  Flavor is sweet rice and mild maltiness.  Finishes weak and little aftertaste.  Not terrible for a premium lager but I won’t buy again.
Nothing interesting here except very nice hoppiness. It was a pleasant surprise: for this hoppiness I could forgive its blandness and lack of character.

Ok, so I poured this beer and put it down about 2 feet away from me so I could start typing, and I could smell skunk all throughout the room.  Wow, could you have any less color.  Bla, this beer taste about as bad as it smells/looks.  I will never intentionally drink this beer again!
Not a beer I would seek out, but not bad with a good pork with black bean sauce.  Better than their Red Dragon beer.

Poured a golden color with a medium white head and some light lacing.  Buttery diactyl, and sweet corn aroma.  Taste was that of sweet malts, possibly some corn as well, and finishing very lightly hoppy.
Crisp and refreshing. Skunky green aroma in a skunky green bottle. Decent hoppy aftertaste. Not bad at all.

My God this beer smells bad!  However, I can live with the taste as long as I don’t enhale.  Taste is reminicent of Alexander Keith’s, not exactly a glowing indorsement to some people but I like it.  Not a beer I’d rush out to buy, but it reminds me of my favorite Chinese dive in Toronto...then again the last time there I got food poisoning.

330ml green bottle from Safeway. Poured a clear amber nicely carbonated with white qd head. Fruity rice aroma with hops note. Nicely balanced crisp light lager flavour. No chemical or metallic flavours& no skunk despite the green bottle. Very long bitter finish. Nice& refreshing.
Not a fan of most lagers...pours as expected...thin white head, nice and yellow :/   Skunky aroma with a hit of hops...MILDLY refreshing...it does go quite well with General Tsao’s chicken though...

Pours yellow and watery with little head. Smells like it comes in a green bottle, and indeed it does. Flavor is bland and comperable to most other asian lagers I have tasted. Overall,  I can’t really justify drinking it unless I’m out at a Chinese restaurant eating some spicy Szechuan quisine.

Aroma is hoppy, slightly malty, skunky and something weird (which should be the rice). Clear, golden coloured with a fast diminishing head. Taste is better than smell. Initially sparkling beer, becomes more bitter. hoppy, (too) sweet and a little floral. Fresh palate, slightly dry. At least it tastes better than I expected.

Bottled, sampled in Restaurant Asia, Zagreb

Golden with mostly vanishing head. Sweet corn/rice aroma. Medium-bodied, crisp, sweetish. Some grassy hops in malt-corn base.(3/2/4/2/7 1.8)

Re-rated, bottled, alc. 4.7 % (bottled 10/2007)

Golden color, creamy white head. Skunky sweet corn aroma, which is not nice. Paperboadish, quite sweet corn/rice flavor. Quickly vanishing flavor.  Yes, Chinese Bud. (2/2/2/2/6 1.4)

Absolutely nothing out of the ordinary with this one, except that it is made in China.  (Hey, aren’t they communist?  What are they doing making beer?  What is the relationship between those two things?  I dunno.)  Anyway, don’ t buy this at a restaurant as it is tooooo pricey for what you get.
This could just be because I had it with a good chinese meal but I quite enjoyed this beer. Bit pricey though.

Pale yellowy appearance, slightly hazed, moderate head formation. Malty, grainy, lightly hopped aroma. Sweet malt intro, slightly coarse and grainy. Dry in the finish with a mild bitterness. Fairly simple, acceptable in a Chinese restaurant.

Sweet kinda maltesqe nose, yellow with minimum head.  Fairly livly in the mouth, sweet but prehaps a bit too much.  Finnished slighly grainy and dry.  No real defining charatoristics.  It wasnt out right bad but it definitly wasnt good.  Prehaps "smuh" is the word Im looking for.
Light golden color, light weak aroma, watery taste, light body, light watery finish. close to water.

Smells vaguely floral and sweet.  Pours a light golden with no head to speak of.  Beer is a bit thicker than i expected, and is actually a bit sweet and decently balanced.  Finish is watery.  No real adjunct flavors, at least.  Easy to drink and very very mild.  I’ve had worse, and i could imagine sort of enjoying it in China.
ooOOo I luv this beer with Chinese food!!  Yummmyy!!  Beautiful nice crisp golden color look.   A good white head.  Traces of bitterness which makes the beer interesting.
I remember having this and thinking "this is the chinese budweiser".  It’s been some time since I’ve had this one.  Tasted of hops and a hint of skunk.
Drinkable beer but kind of boring and very light. It is very thirst quenching and hey, it’s NOT a Bud and doesn’t leave a nasty aftertaste. Very crisp and refreshing.
Tried at O.C.  Not impressed at all.  Right up there with Sapporo and Kirin Ichiban.  If you like Bud, this beers for you!

Why is it that un-/under- developed countries produce bad beer? Is it a requirement? Pours yellow - big shock there. Smells slightly skunked but otherwise sweet with notes of corn - another surprise. Taste is not too awful. Again sweet, and a bit crisp. Mild hops. Better than most of them. Finish is slightly bittersweet. Not the worst but it continues a bad trend.

ok, here we go. I drank this beer for one simple reason last year. It apparently was "the year of the ram" in Chinese mythology, and the greatest football team in the league is the St. Louis Rams... this was the only reason I drank the beer. Overall this beer is very simple.
Deep straw in color with a small white head.Mild skunk aroma with a touch of hops. Clean malt charcater with mild hop flavor and a clean dry finish.
Pretty much a typical light lager, crisp and clean with a medium hoppy bite.  Went well with my General Tso’s chicken.
Clear golden blond beer with a small head. The aroma is light sweet and hoppy. The taste is rather standard lager. The bitterness is light.

Highly carbonated yellow body topped with a thick but quick fading head. Due to the green bottle, the beer exhales a skunky aroma in the first stage. Then comes a weak malty perfume. Taste is watery and lightly bitter. Palate is close to none. I am not disappointed because I wasn’t expecting more than a cheap macro lager.

This has got to be one of the worst beers i ever had to suffer.Even with a chinese meal it´s so f***ing bland and boring.If this is made from spring water then the chinese authority have a serious problem with water polution.

pour yellow med size head that didn’t last little to no lacing. aroma some malts and hops and rice skunky. taste skunky with some bitterness.went well with the chinese food.This is one of those beers you want ice cold and it is better than bud.
Eh. Watery, flat and decidely undistinctive on all counts. Definite skunkiness. I can’t recommend this beer anyone, but the name is fun to say.
A watery mess.  Bland to the dull end.  Ricey ending gives a sicky sweetness.  Should have known better.
Bottle: Pale yellow with small head. Taste is flat and stale with some hints of rice.

The only thing that I like about this lager is listening to goober try to pronounce it. If you are a 14 year old reading this, please say "CHING-DOW." I will from time to time order this at a chinese restaurant when I’m dining on something really spicy. You see, the ethanol is really the only saving grace to this fluid. Does this brewery really import yeast and malted barley to make this? I didn’t know that China imported anything...

Bottled.  Pale golden beer with a fine, steadily rising head. Strong rice aroma and flavour. The first sniff and taste of this beer send you reaching immediately for the details on the bottle. ‘Rice’ stands out proudly on the bottom of the label. Not a great larger but at least they're not hiding the fact they use adjuncts. Low bitterness and a distinct lack of malt and hops.

Bottle:  As soon as I poured the beer I could smell the skunkiness from arms length.  Pale yellow in appearance with a good white head.  Tasted just as bad as it smelled, skunky.  Bitter aftertaste.  I’m sure this was just a really bad skunked beer, but to date this is the worst beer I’ve ever had and I can’t see myself giving it a second chance to see if it was just a bad bottle.

*******Re-Rate*******
OK, I summoned the courage to try this again and it was not as bad as the first time.  Still skunky, but not as overpoweringly skunky as my first attempt.  Still not good, but not as bad as my initial rating of 0.8.  I must have had a really bad bottle.
Bottled. Why green bottles I’ll never know. Beer smelled and tasted skunky. Once you get past that tasted like any other lager.

Very pale yellow pour. Rocky head and some spotty lacing. Very sharp notes of malts and a bit of hops. Slightly yeasty. Flavor not so acrid. The hops are citrusy and the malts are sweet. Bitter finish to an average pils.
Smells really skunky but the taste isnt bad. This is good to have with some chinese left overs
This used to be my favorite beer. Then i think i over did it. Now, it's just nice to have here and there, but nothing special anymore.
A bit like drinking liquid straw although not the worst pils I have tasted. Thinnish body with no real edge to it. Not one I would try again.

Poured with very large head over a standard-looking yellow and relatively still beer.  I could smell the very sweet malt from 2 feet away as the head settled; up closer a bit of citrus comes through to the nose.  This is a mellow drinker, with a tartness the primary flavoring.  Other than being terribly watery-feeling, this isn't as bad as I'd feared.  Could balance well with Soy Sauce-soaked munchies.

Bottled. Best I can say about this is it lets me paste a "China" stamp in my album of country statistics. Big foamy head at pour that hangs around too long. Pale straw color, and generic "beer" smell. Hard to get a good sip out from under the hunka foam. Taste makes me yearn for the more complex flavor profile of a Budweiser. After some effort, I can taste a little malt sweetness and a slightly bitter aftertaste. To paraphrase the old stereotype, it takes much less than an hour again for me to be thirsty... for a real beer. Again, it doesn't taste bad per se, just has no taste at all.
(Bottle)  Pours a pale yellow color with a foamy white head.  Has an aroma of wet grass. Okay for a pilsner...

Common in Chinese restaurants, and it does fairly well with that cuisine.  Otherwise, I don't think so.  Originally, germans assisted in the founding of the brewery, and their heritage is evident in the Pilsener color if nowhere else.  Rice (I suspect) is used as a brewing adjunct, and the flavor is affected thereby.  As i said, only with Hunan chicken...
Skunky green bottle + adjuncts galore + cheapness = Chinese Budweiser.  Not by any means enjoyable - I could've gotten Bud Light for a dollar less.

A nice green bottle skunk aroma. Appearance is pee-pee yellow. Oh I dread this one.....A funny hay and adjunct flavor. Skunk-o-rama. Piss poor beer even for a lager. I'd rather have an American Standard in a can. This sucks!
Was something nice to try since it was a chinese beer.  However it reminded me of a light lager.  Nothing spectacular.
hmmmmmmm pours yellow, sweet taste, this beer isnt very good BUT it is GREAT with chinese food.  i usually have 6 pack of it around so i can drink 1 or 2 when i get chinese food.
this yellow beer had minimal head atop and smelled like sweet sushi rice...bland but unoffensive flavors...mildy sweet...actually, not really all that bad for what it is..
Had this one with Japanese food.  Fairly good aroma, half decent taste.  Slightly hoppy and citrusy at the finish.  I wouldn't buy it again, but not too bad.
I guess i had a fresh bottle has the nose was faint malt, no skunk around here. The taste says adjunct but the bitterness saves this beer, as it makes it crisp. Very light and bland body.
I see that this beer doesn't get good ratings, but I liked it. Nice mellow beer, light and drinkable. Very impressed with it. Not what I expected from China.

Very pale straw colored body with a frothy white short lived head fed by fake carbonation. Clean grainy malt smell with notes of grassy hops. Cloyingly sweet diluted corn syrup like taste is pretty bad. A touch of hops in the aftertaste make this a bit more drinkable than it would otherwise be. On par with mass produced beers from the big three, and only worth sampling as a novelty. My Chinese friend at work handed this to me as a free sample. I would not buy it, and I’ll have to try to get him to sample some of the better pale lagers so that he wouldn’t either.

A standard bud like beer.  Golden colored, skunky in the nose, light bodied, watery on the palate, very mild malt and hop flavors that seem to clash.  It'll do, when it's your only choice in a chinese restaurant.

June, 2002 I have heard that this beer is very variable, but can be quite spicy and refreshing. Mine was obviously of the poor variety - soapy-sweet selotape. [1.4]
 
March, 2004 Pale yellow. Clean & crisp. Huge cow pat malt aroma. Surprisingly attractive. Some light bitterness. Not much happening, but an acceptable and refreshing drink. [2.2] 

April, 2007 On tap at the Noodle House in Gillingham. Crisp and drinkable. Most of the character appears to come from the carbonation,  and the main element of this beer is that it is inoffensive. [2.0]
Skunky, watery, bitter. Not good, but it does cool the mouth after too much wasabi.
Very skunky aroma. Thin white head recedes completely on light golden body. Mild bitterness and sweet finish. Fizzy carbonation. Bottle (green).

Carbonated, clear straw body topped by quickly dissipating off-white head.  Aroma is light skunk on the pour, but turns grassy with some grainy.  Taste is mild -- medium sweet, grassy and grainy.  FInishes with some dryness and minimal bitterness.  Grainy and faintly grassy burp.  Mild acidity in a light-medium body.  Not bad, but its strength is its inoffensiveness.

Sample- 355 ML bottle- Poured a short lived white head. It lasted as long as the head would on a glass of cola. Light hoppy taste with the same aroma to match. Went down smooth, and was suprisingly refreshing. Nothing out of the ordinary though.

Only thing wrong with the aroma was the lack. In fact that is pretty much how I'd sum this whole beer up. Everything is okay but now done much, Kind of reminded me of Steinlager but with even less prominent features. Slightly more expensive than Steinlager as well. 

Little side note, as it gets warmer a funny little taste becomes apparent (it is a hot day) I don't recall this flavor, it is kind of a metallic touch on the tip of your tongue, I am wondering if this is because of the rice that the label mentions? It is something odd anyhow.
Didn't seem hoppy enough to be a pils but it did have more flavor than I expected. No head. Aroma is minimal, grassy. Not bad with the Chinese food.

bottled:  ive had this several times with my chinese food or sushi or even thai.  good clean beer if your drinking spicy stuff...my friend call this the 'happy' beer, go figure. if you drink too many of them your 'happy'. this one has that kinda skunk smell to it always?? nothing to say about the look , its typical. however, the taste is a bit more sweet here then in the other asian style pilseners.  and of course there is some adjunct taste going on...always a good guess would be rice. ya di ya da ya da.

Extremely more-ish. The best of the Commie beers I've had. Its a sprightly drop and great with asain food.
Spanner.
Pale golden colour with fairly thin white head.  Strong scent of fruit, flowers, and honey over a nice light malt.  Floral taste with a crisp finish.  Pretty good with anything spicy.
Light gold with minimal head. Lots of carbonation. Finishes clean and hoppy. It's nothing special.
Light golden, medium head, no lace. Mild aroma with some cookie like crisp malt. Light to medium body. Moderate bitter, a bit sweet, notes of crisp cookie-like malt. More bitter, sweeter finish.
tried this beer as part of the around the world club.  it's about what i expected - not a good beer!  but what do you expect from china!
Thin beer with off flavors. Not too appealing. This beer has a long way to go to be a drinkable beer.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a watered down piss-yellow with a medium amount of virgin white head that dissipates quickly but leaves a thin, soapy-looking film of sudsy head.  Aroma is of straw, grass, vegetal on a cool spring day.  Flavor is a watered down crappy yellow beer, straw, grass, vegetal.  Not offensive, but certainly no good reason to injest anymore of it.  Sampled at 67 degrees Fahrenheit.
Very pale gold colour with white medium size lasting head. Harsh  rice? nose and the taste is of floral hops with a watery texture.
Between the time when a bottle gets capped in China to when someone buys it at a Chinese buffet in Minnesota, this beer turns into skunk water. I would like to try it fresh if ever given the chance.

I'm not sure whether I'm smelling rice or very mild hops, but there's a hint of skunk to it anyway.

Carbonation seems to be the order of the day for my ratings tonight. Otherwise it's yellow with a modest layer of head.

I used to like this beer from the can once. Now I know why; the green glass bottles do it no favours. This bottle has traveled to far and sat to long on a shelf in a well lit shop.

Otherwise the taste is mild and watery. Would do OK with some Thai-takeaway, if the beer was fresh. Otherwise there's not much going on for it. Too sweet by far, really.
Skunky hop aroma.Light gold appearance with smallish head.Dry watery skunky hop flavor with a little bread dough flavor.

I sometimes drink this beer at my local Dim Sum pusher! It is a very light pilsener but it has some kind of interesting crispy feeling to it (almost like Champagne....). Very thin and watery with very little flavor.
Bottle. This is pretty standard fare, but it does have a nice chalky quality to it, and is reassuringly crisp.  This is a classic session beer for a night down the Arcadian Centre in Birmingham.

Lacy, wispy, creamy head.  High-maltiness to the nose and to the taste buds as well.  Rich tasting.  A clear, golden hue.  Taste is ultimately thin and sweet.  Watery.  Reminds me a little of a Riesling wine.  Similarly, it also makes a pleasant companion to eclectic and spicy Chinese or other Asiatic cuisines.

Bought this in a 22 oz green bottle,
Poured very nicelly into the glass quite an impressive head for a lager beer..went down a bit but still nice. Good golden colour.
Smells pretty good too some malt light hops.
Taste however is pretty average..its not bad but its hardly good.
Feels light in the mouth and its drinkable..I bought this to go along with the Szechuan chicken i prepared at home..it does a good job with this spicy dish

I was anything but impressed with this beer. Not recommended unless you are truly into Pilseners. It poured a small sized white head that was smooth with fine-small sized bubbles that mostly diminished. The body had very, very little carbonation and it was clear with a yellow hue. The nose was malty as was the flavor. The palate was tingly and watery and light bodied. The lacing was very sparse.
Straight forward, Floral on the nose. Herbal and medicinal. Is the only beer i have tried that is very rich but light and easy drinking. Fair. Wont jump to buy again.
Had a thick white head that didn't stay around. The smell suggests malt and hops, but still doesn't  have a lot of flavor.

This brew poured a small head of fine to large sized white colored mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a transparent softly carbonated straw yellow colored body and a minimal lace.  The aroma was a very mild malt hop one.  The mouthfeel was tingly and bubbly from its start to its finish.  The flavor was a typical malt hop one with a little bite and bitterness.
Pilsner color. No head. Skunky smell and flavor. Floral and metallic as well. Smooth and bitter in the aftertaste but not a very nice beer.
Bottled, Pasteurised. Pale insipid yellow beer, thin head. Thin, watery flavour, a little hop impact saves the day but won't be searching it out.
The color is light yellow.  The smell is reminescent of sweat socks.  The flavor is of a poor domestic.
Very light for a pilsner style. Watery, no aftertaste. Very light golden color with a light head that disappears quickly. I agree with the floral aroma/taste assessment.
First Chinese beer I've had. Was expecting the worst since I don't like many Chinese foods and I was proven wrong. A little watery but not bad
Floral aroma, tastes a bit florally too, a bit unususual, a bit watery, a bit simple.  cheers
This tasted like a watered down skunky moosehead. That's about the best description I can give.
Light yellow colour, little or no head.  Bit of hoppy bitterness. Not bad considering what it is. Had it at Mandarin Chinese Buffet :)
Blonde color. Very thin nose. Simple body, some malt, very light sweetness. Simple finish.

I've had this on tap in Hong Kong, very refreshing beer there.  This was perhaps the best bottle I've ever consumed in the states.  Very light pilsener coloration, a bit fizzy.  Floral nose.  Floral hops also dominate the flavor.  Rather nice, really, and very refreshing.  Not a complex beer, but enjoyable.  Very prone to skunking horribly though.

Skunky toast aroma, light hops pushing through. I drank half of this and poured the rest into a pot of cooking bratwursts. The taste was light and malty but the skunkiness was a little too pronounced for my tastes.
I wish I could be more constructive, but this just tasted like skunked Molson.
The commercial description touts the water used to brew the beer, thus (in my mind) making it the Chinese equivalent to Olympia. 'nuff said.
Not that bad of a beer, but could be so much better if it were not skunked. Kind of reminds me of Heineken, with the skunkiness and bitterness. Crisp and somewhat refreshing.
Run of the mill, mass produced beer.  Pleasant hint of hops in the nose.  Don't mean to seem unpatriotic, but I'll drink it.

This sucks chicken balls. Basically a sweeter equivalent of American macrobrew garbage, with slight MSG notes. I suppose it does work with spicy food -- and it smells sneakily beerlike -- but there is no reason to order this except to sound somewhat cool at an Asian restaurant. And even that’s a stretch.

Pale-yellow, fast-fading pure white head, and moderate carbonation. Initial smell was of that green-bottle skunk cloud that escapes immediately upon opening, like an evil, stinky, Chinese spirit in this case. After the spirit diffused, the aroma was of wheat, yeast, and some grassy hops. Flavor is rather bland... like straw and raw corn and the finish has a stale bitterness to it. A passable beer with Chinese food (or in celebration of Chinese New Year), otherwise this beer is pointless to drink.
pale yellow, small white head.  grainy malt and mild grassy hop aroma.  starts cereal-ish and finishes with decent bitterness.  not bad, but not great.

So soft golden color it almost has no color.  the skunky aroma made me think of that dead skunk on I-93.  it wafted out of the bottle and squinched up my nose on contact. it's like budcoorsmiller opened shop in China.
Significant hoppy aroma but taste is supprising as it is predominantly malty / sweet.  God color with a white mostly diminishing head.  unremarkable beer but drinkable.

Light color full but quick disappearing head,slight hop aromahighly bubbly,a faint hoptaste, absolutly no aftertaste, has texture and mouthfeel of an American light beer. Very simple,like a seltzer water. Doesnt complement Chinnese food that well, unless you enjoy the cleansing of the mouth effect it has, whereby you savor your food more. A gulping beer, strictly to quench thirst

this is only the second asian brew i ever had,the first one i had was saporro from japan and i really enjoyed it.so recently when i spotted this chinese beer in my local liquor store ,i was really anxious to give it try.i was expecting another decent beer like saporro,man was i dissappointment.the taste is very skunky and the aftertaste is even worst.i bought a six pack of this and could'nt even finish one of them,gave the rest to my friend and he did'nt like it either.i would'nt recommend this beer to anyone.
With this stuff for competition.  It's no wonder Budweiser does so well in Asia.  Limit this one to when you go out for Chinese.

This beer pours a light golden color with a small head and no lacing on the glass.  The aroma is slightly skunky and unintersting.  The flavor is somewhat skunky - reminescent of Heineken but slightly better.  It's a little sweet and fairly crisp, but still not very enjoyable.
Didn't care for the taste of this one at all. Looked ok coming out of the bottle. One sip and that was it. I don't reccommend this one to anybody. Steer clear.

Not a big fan. China should stick to being a large communist nation.  The aroma was that of soured hops, and the flavor was close to the same.  This beer didn't even go well with my food (guess which kind).
Uggh. Unpleasant aroma. Pale in color and even paler in taste. Appropriately loaded with rice. Not good.
Very skunky unpleasant aroma. Light rice taste, tolerable, but a little boring, they could at least use brown bottles when exporting to north america.
It's like the "Hue" Watery so it is refresing. Its doesn't really have a taste ... Probably it could be good with spicy food.

Where there is nothing particularly offensive about this beer, there is really nothing much to it either.  Watery, with some hoppiness but not much, and really pretty dull.  I could see a long cold one drunk in a couple of seconds on a hot day would be good, but so would just about anything.

One of my favorite "crap beers", I often have a bottle when I go to a Chinese restaurant... mainly because it's cheap. Pale yellow colour; shortly lasting, small to average in size. Faint, sweetish aroma and taste. Crisp enough to be refreshing, especially when you find a fresh bottle, which is not always easy. You can often detect traces of cardboard in the finish.
Barely noticeable aroma of hops.  Light yellow.  Hardly any taste at all.  Thin.  This beer has nothing to offer.

This pilsener beer pours a clear golden color with a small, fizzy white head that does not linger. The aroma is slightly hoppy and grassy with a bit of sweetness from the malts and corn. It has a light body with moderate carbonation and a smooth, slightly watery mouthfeel. The flavor is slightly sweet and the hops show themselves briefly in the finish. Not bad, drinkable with no off flavors, though the flavor it does have is not very impressive. This would make a good, light beer to go with some Asian dishes.

Color is a pale to clear yellow with a small white head, some very small tight lacing. Smell is faintly sweet and some grain as in bread thats soft in the back. Taste is clean and sweet with a grainy backing thats lightly bread-like and finishes with a small bitter hop bit that drys slightly. Feel is light, crisp, and clean with a sweetning thats light and finishes slightly dry and bitter from hop. This was very refreshing to have with my mildly spicey thai food. Would settle for this over many other Asian imports.
Clear pale yellow/ White, pillowy head. Light malt aroma (& slight skunk). Sugary body. Watery, light malt flavour. Very little bitterness.Somewhat harsh.
Gold color with small white head. Very little aroma. Modest malt flavor with very little hops. OK with my Flaming Phoenix.
I liked this beer.  It is a very mild beer and not the least bit substantial.  However, it drank quite smoothly and left no bad aftertaste.  Give it a try.
Not bad at all for an Asian beer.  Actually rather crisp and pleasant.  Try it with Vietnamese food.  Cools it down just right.
Clear, light yellow in color with little to no head. Lighly malt flavor with light floral notes. Light malt flavor, sweet. Fizzy and enemic, not recommended.

Very pale yellow color.  Fizzy white quickly dissipitating head.  The nose is extremely skunked, I doubt one could find a fresh version outside of China.  Also hints of slight grass and light sugar.  The body has a light spritz at the beginning with a surprising light hop bitterness.  Gets into some sugar at the close and finishes dry and sprtizy with just a touch of dust.  I'm sure there must be better beers in China.

I was expecting alot worse. I was expecting something like the american budweiser, with an overwhelming piss and rice taste. This was alot better, nice yeasty aroma, some hints of rice, a very refreshing brew
This isn't too bad. Poured a light straw yellow with nearly no head and almost non existant lacing. Light but pleasant flavor. Moderate carbonation. This might be Decent on a hot day.

This is NOT the people's beer, as it is a joint venture...but anyway, this is the finest China has to offer, having had it there.  Certainly better than Yanjing, Chongqing, or any of the other state-run brews.  Being that you either get those, or Budweiser (Wuhan brewery) or this, I would take this while you're there.

The people's beer...Smells a bit like skunked apple juice would, if I ever had it. A little more hops and malt than average cheap American beer. Ok all around once and a while, but not so good really. You think Mao would be proud?
Very crisp palate, noble hop nose, long, bitter-balanced finish. I like this beer. Its not Pilsner Urquell, but I'd take it over Heiney or Stella anyday.

Pale golden color with a sickly, soapy looking white head. The aroma and flavor were so bland that I had a hard time picking anything out. Surprisingly, I got no rice or corn in the aroma...extremely mild hops...some sweetness. The flavor was mildy sweet with an ocassional hint of hops. Watery feel...very very light. Because it was so bland I really can't say much about this beer.
Had this while visiting hong kong.  Seemed like the budweiser of china.  Served its purpose on those humid 43 C days spent watching the junks on the harbour.

Grainy aroma. Yellow golden color, white head, few lace. Maltsweet, rahter full but grainy. Short malty finish. Although not really a very bad brew I couldn't finish it because of it's grainy fullness.

This beer poured with no head and was very light yellow in color.  The color, aroma and taste reminded me a lot of Miller High Life.  Not a lot going on with this beer, however it would be great after cutting the grass on a hot summer day.  Not highly carbonated and slightly sweet in taste.
This is the original kung fu beer! Not impressive taste-wise, but has a very old-skool kitsch appeal. A cheapo light cool beer to enjoy by the roadside stall.

At AIBA 2003. Regular Asian rice beer. Normal appearance with decent head. Flavour is not as bad as expected but not bitter enough. Advice by the brewer's rep. is to always serve very cold, not surprising
Had this over Chinese food, which was probably not a great idea anyway.  Fizzy, almost carbonated, light golden color, very little head or nose, and a dull flavor.  Not impressive.
I like this beer, it is light and refreshing still tastes very good, a bit malty and very nice, mild hops.
At first, it looks and tastes like an ordinary draft beer, but the hops stands out and there is a slight hint of originality in the malt. Not a bad lighter beer.
I really don't like this stuff.  Reminds me of a heavily rice-based bad pilsner.  Very thin, bitter and acidic, too biting.

Not much on the aroma side, slightly fruity. Typical pilsener appearance, pouring light yellow with high carbonation. Has an unusual buttery palate that was not unpleasant. Better than I expected but lacks the crisp finish of a high quality pilsener.
Very pale appearance. Very different flavour, quite crisp. Head is unremarkable. Still, better than most macro-brews.
A surprising beer - I didn't expect much from China, but came away pleasantly surprised.  I won't eat chinese food without a stubby now and find it's crisp, lightness a perfect partner for it
Thin aroma not much to comment on, got a slight waft on malt.  Hoppy taste with hints of peach.  This is a very thin beer with vitually no after taste.  Its a bit like a weak IPA.

Rerate 10/25/04 Just nothing to really get excited about with this one - just an ordinary Asian lager; thin dry, slightly bland. Slight hop presence. Original 2.8 Not a bad way to kill 10 minutes while waiting for my Chinese take out.  Olive oil-like aroma, unusual, but not unpleasant.  Little to no head - but what is there has a lot of lacing. Very dry flavor - leaves you thirsty almost! Quite a bite to it. Stays strong throughout.
Aroma reminds me of rice,has little head, but is very smooth.  Has a short, fruity finish.  Not bad, not great.
Yellow, no head, sweet skunky nose, bland. Maybe spicy Chinese mustard would go well with this, but so does water.
Little head, pilsener odor. Flavors to match, dry finish. Nothing special, but not horrible either.

What did I just run over.  This takes the cake when it comes to skunky smell.  Wow.  Head was small and flavour was stinky and rather bland.  Quite fizzy with an unpleasant finish.  With all the people in China, there must be better beers.  Bring them and I will sip away.
Holy lord... it's like drinking a skunk.  This stuff is like liquid death.  I actually think Bud might be better than this.
I had this at a chinese restaurant just for kicks. I had hoped for much more.
Pathetically weak and...pathetic.  A totally lame, crisp and fizzy excuse for beer.
Somewhat skunky and flowery aroma. White frothy head that quickly diminishes. Light gold colour. Light bitter taste to start, finishes acidic. Unpleasant fizzy, almost sharp feel. Not great.

Well, it's good to drink this beer when you're at a Chinese restaurant, because its flavour (not particular tasty nor hoppy or malty) is not bad and helps to eat the spicy food. But I actually would never buy this beer to drink at home...
Good beer to drink when you are at a Chinese restaurant. It's light and kind of watery. It's also sweet and malty. It's only worth drinking at a chinese restaurant.

Why is it that there are almost no good Asian brews? It's almost like the second coming of South America. Okay, my ethnocentricism has just attained new unforseen levels, but I mean, this beer what boorrring. Refreshing? Maybe. Fizzy yellow water? Most definitely.
Not overly impressed. The color speaks of water added to beer. The aroma I associate with chinese food.... The actual taste is something hard to remember... it blends into that american standard cat.

This beer was a little too malty for my taste, almost a warm buttery taste at first, followed by a heineken-esque flavor.  I had this while eating chinese food and it went very well with the meal.  Has a very cloudy pale look while being poured with almost no head at all.  Nothing about this beer really screams drink me.
Reminds me of Heineken. Nice malty taste but could use more hop bitterness. Goes good with Thai food.
Much like a traditional pilsner. It has a bit of metallic aroma.............
Highly malted yes, highly hopped?....nope. Your normal malty Chinese beer...
watery taste with some hints of malts. A bit of a bitterness. Not much there...

Why did I drink this? Well, my "friend" Libby brought me a bottle, and well, it''s been years since I tried it, so there I went.  This brew was dominated by an off tasting, metallic hop bitterness.  Another odd thing - the palate was somewhat full on my tongue, but at the same time felt watery on the roof of my mouth.  that''s weird.  This would be a totally acceptable beverage if you''re eating something hot''n''spicy.  When you ask your "friends" to bring you beer, you''d better be specific!!!!
Smells worse than it taste--and taste is not extraordinary.  Very carbonated, making it more refreshing.  Needs to be drank fast when you are hot and thirsy otherwise do not bother.
I enjoy this beer.  Clean tasting with a good aroma , nice hop flavor and finish.  Perfect balance.
Straw color, thin head. Bland but not bad. A microscopic trace of fruityness and a little bit of hops. Thankfully, not a trace of skunkiness unlike other imported pilsners.
Bottled(330ml). good with chineese food, malty flavour, nice aroma, refreshing
This beer just plain sucked!  No body, taste or apperance, this tasted more like soda with a kick than a beer!  I will not try it again.
A well rounded beer overall. Nice looking bottle too. ......................

China makes beer.. Yes  It isn''t that bad either. Although I have not had it for some time
Would be good to sample it again but from what I remember it was okay
a decent beer from a place you wouldn''t think of. nothing too special..and does have some heineken taste in it. but it''s a decent beer.
If I had a choice between this one and trying something that I know nothing about, I would choose the unknown beer.
China - not the place I think of when I think of beer. Sweet, and the first that tasted fresh, but - the Bud of China? Miller?
Pleasent, light flavour. Good with chicken or fish?.........................
Bottle, ABV 4,5%: Colour is light golden. NOt much head. Has a hoppy aroma. Flavour is hoppy and a bit sweet. Dosn''t have much bitterness for a pilsener. Very refreshing.
Overall a very refreshing beer, although it drinks more like a lager than a pilsener.  Kinda has that watery Moosehead flare.

Well, It goes well with food, in the sense that it doesn't have enough flavor to interfere with it. Not bad in any specific way; It's just once you get past the "Hey! Chinese beer!" factor, it isn't terribly unique.

A golden beer with a small but OK head. It has a very hoppy aroma. And a very fresh prickling flavor - do I detect some brewing cereal? It has a nice bitterness - but for me new type of hoppiness. A very refreshing beer.
Nice grain in the aroma.  Quite a sweet malty lager with not much in the way of bitterness.  Not too bad.
This is a fairly decent, American style pilsener.  I prefer this to most domestic beers, and as far as lagers go, this is not too bad.
A very average pils.  Mimics the American Standard in everyway.  It is a refreshing, but lacks any substantive hop or malt presence.  Could be drank in quantity on a hot day.
Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the temple of forbidden hops, please take your shoes off and dip your smelly feet in the vat right here...
yuck!  not even good with chinese food!  I''d prefer a bud over this crap!..
White gold color. Skimpy head. Lightly malted flavor. Decently hopped. Should wash down my sechzuan chicken nicly.
Light gold color, white head that diminished quickly. Light pils, refreshing but nothing to travel to China for. Much better beers right here in the good old USA.
I expected crap but this ain''t a bad pislner at all.  Not too hoppy, which I find often spoils a pilsner.  Light and refreshing.
OK with Chineese food, but I wouldn't buy it my everyday brew. A tad weak...

Dry, crisp, clean, nice hops.  Good white bubbly head.  Nothing too distinguishing but nothing that detracts from a clean beverage.  Better than most american standards and not a bad pilsener just somewhat light.
Can.  Pretty typical Asian lager.  Minimal to no head.  Aroma is slightly floral.  The flavor is weak but not offensive.  I bought this in Hong Kong.
Bad, bad aroma and flavour I think fanta is much better.....................
My first Tsingtao was really bad (0.5), but a couple of days ago I had another one, which wasn't that awful.
Good example of a nice far eastern beer, pilsener in every aspect...........

Light, wattery, but has a mild champagne dryness.  It has sort of a rice taste to it.  I can drink this stuff and it's a got a potent kick to it, but I wouldn't call it excellent.  It's an average beer- like a Chinese Bud-Light.  Overpriced, but nice with a spicy Tofu dish.  Little carbonation and light head. Pretty refreshing, but not exceptional.

I actually really liked this beer! But with a strength just greater than water you have to drink a lot of it to "get that happy feeling", which invariably means plenty of trips to the loo!
Nice beer but...
Light and watery, I don't see "high-malty flavor and well-hopped character" the only thing I taste is a skunk.
This beer is over priced. Kinda skunky......................................
Pretty strong hoppy aroma but a very flat flavour of sweet malt and bubbles.
Boring looking, plae yellow, not much carb.  It's got that "is it skunky, is is supposed to be like that?" hopp aroma.  Bitter, but not in a good way.  Pretty watery, but sort of dry at the very end.
China should stick to executions.   grassy aroma, yellow piss color, head disipates quickly.   kind of sweet, wierd burning sensation deep in the cheeks.   unimpresive

Clear pale gold with zero head. Very faint hint of mild hops aroma. Very light body with faint stale hop bitter flavoured start. Limp sweetish watery cordial like finish. Two mouthfuls were sufficient.
Not so horrible with Fried Rice. It just doesn't stand up by itself though. That being said I have had much worse. If someone else is buying I'll drink a few. If I'm buying, I'd have to pass.

Very pale appearance, same shade as the white wine others were drinking, low carbonation. Very watery, slight hops – the alcohol is very noticeable. Tastes almost as if it is just water and alcohol mixed. If anything it is good refreshment with spicy food.
Watery and bland.  Not much to this one.  In my opinion, better left alone.
A little like the sourtheast asian beer, tsinga.  You can taste the rice.  Still very smooth and lager-y.
Rather unassuming beer with very little charecter. Tasted and looked like alot of american macro swill.

Thin nasty looking brew.  Not a good aroma.  The most disturbing thing that I heard is that they add a little formeldahyde to preserve the flavor.  The bottle I had was dusty in a green glass and tasted as fresh as the day it was brewed.  YOu draw your own conclusions.
The little Chinese place nearby lets you BYOB and that is a much better idea than succumbing to the strange acidity of this stuff.
Interesting but not extraordinary...........................................
Pretty neutral feelings.  It reminds me of Peroni or Bierra Moretti, but a little better.  I am not exactly sure what makes it better, though.
Pale golden color with little head.  sour aroma and little flavor.  Good beer for someone who doesn't like any flavor.
This is almost clear.  Watery and clean on the tongue.  Definitely something there, but not sure what.  Good with food, but not as the main course.
Only slight fruity aroma. Apple and orange in the taste. Just a bit sour and a bit sharp. No noticeable finish.

Light, light, light.  You can tell that some hops were used in the brewing of this beer, though.
Pleasant, innocuous and forgettable.  It's a sad commentary, though, that I'd drink this over MilBudCoors anytime.

I was in a Chinese restaurant and thought, heck, why not.  Not bad at all, the bottle tricks you into thinking it's like a heinekin or a green beer but, don't be fooled, it good.  Would recommend it, for your chinese dining.

this heathen pinko-commie beer is bright yellow like a vintage pair of ray-ban aviators.  tho the beer is still sitting here, i can't recall the head, we so briefly met. aroma? no, not really. imagine a beer "scratch n' sniff", that's how full the nose is. i am happy to observe, however, that no skunks were harmed in the making of this green bottled 	 beer. it has some  fresh magazine paper notes, and a bag of pretzels held at arm's lenghth. smallish carbonation, very small flavor, diminutive hop bite-- and miniscule chance i'll ever buy it again.

Aroma a little sweet, a little hoppy, but only a little of both. Color is medium-pale gold--head average, i.e. acceptable...Flavor medium-light blend of hops and malt--but hoppiness the more distinctive.  This is one I only drink at Chinese or Thai restaurants, but it seems to successfully navigate those culinary waters, because I continue to order it.

hmm its one of those, kirin, red stripe, kingfisher, class beers, but you know what. i love it. such an easy drink, great with thai food. has one good shot of bitter hops and then its through. much better than most asian beers ive tried.

Hoppy, sweet aroma, bit of adjunct. Weak but pleasant. Bright amber color with slight head. Medium, watery body and medium carbonation. Crisp and refreshing. Slightly sweet with mild bitter end and after. A nice everyday beer, really good with spicy food.
Clarity,lack of aroma, crispness and body. However the flavor is there, czech hops, sweet fruity ending.

Light gold - med creamy head.  Weak aroma: light skunk and cooked rice.  Somewhat vegetal - cooked onions?  Smells strangely like the food its often served with.  Mostly clean and bland - a little bitterness.  Either my palate has overly adapted tonight or this is one seriously bland beer.
Light bodied with peculiar, different sweet flavour. Still, nothing special.
An ordinary blonde color with the faint corn/rice--beer aroma of mass produced, peroxided beers. Easy, clean flavor.  While this beer does nothing to test the palate, it is palatable.

Roast grain and slightly skunked aroma.  Medium gold and fair head, fading to a border lace.  Bready, sweet, grainy.  Above average pilsener.  I was ready to savage this beer, but was pleasantly surprised.  Very German/Czech tasting, though lightly hopped.

A waste of good rice.  The aroma I got was disgusting--not inappropriate to say it reminded me of a garbage pile, but also like the starch residue on a cooking pot when you leave it sit out overnight after making rice.  The color was amazing--highly artificial translucence in an ugly urine-yellow.  The flavor was only slightly better.  This was a drain pour, literally, after half the bottle.
It wasn't that bad and if i was at the chinese restaurant i'd order one again

I'd like to thank my good friend Jon for drinking bad beer when we went to a happy hour after work, so that I could have a sip and incrase my number of ratings by one for free.  Plus, I could rate a bad beer on a sip instead of having to invest in an entire bottle.  Yuck!!  Quickly dissipating foamy head, very clear and watery.  Awful smell, I swore that it reeked of garbage.

I really enjoyed reading the many entertaining comments and ratings left in regards to this beer.  In fact, I enjoyed them more than I did the beer itself.  I would actually rather drink ice water, yes, even with my Chinese food.

Bloody hell these boys know how to destroy beer. What a stench. Tastes like stale twisties. 

Do not drink this.
Only drinkable in a Chinese restaurant. I would never purchase it in a store.

I always look forward to grabbing a few of these at my favorite Chinese restaurant.  I was more than pleasantly surprised the first time I tried this.*Re-rate* This brew pours with a clear golden light body and lively carbonation.  The mostly diminishing head is frothy white and average sized with fair lacing.  The nose is light with hints of caramel, and flowers.  The initial flavor is malt sweetness. The finish is well balanced.  The texture is light and crisp and clean at the finish.  Both flavor and nose improve drastically as brew approaches cellar temperature.
Light malt nose and piss yellow color. Stale cardboardy taste. Thin. Not good.
First hoppy aroma - whoever, it looks ugly yellow and tastes like water with a little sign of hops. There is bottled water with more flavour than this beer!
Low , faintly malty aroma. No head and straw coloured. Sweet malt in the mouth quickly disappears in the aftertaste which becomes dry and flavourless.

Grainy, pilsner aroma which was typicaly uninteresting. Palate is full bodied for a pils, watery middle, finishes balanced with  a little malt. Not that bad, I could probably get sloppy off this one if I was looking for a pounder, but would probably just choose a cheap American if I was in the market for somethin' like this.
Once I finally tasted it, it tasted totally like Rolling Rock. Not a good thing. My fingers sure are sore as hell from lifting the bottle with chopsticks though.
Not a very good pilsener at all.  Too skunky for me, and  avery unexciting hops flavor.  Nothing too special.
It isn't a bad brew, but I wasn't impressed.  You can find plenty of American beers that are equal to this pilsner so why buy communist?
Like all non-Canadian/European beer, it's watery and too carbonated.........
This beer was only saved by the spicy food  that accompanied it.  Not worth the cash!

Clear, yellow/light orange, watery, medium white quickly dissipating head.  Aroma mostly skunk, though there's a bit of maltiness struggling through.  Flavor starts out not bad at all, watery and thin but somewhat sweet and certainly less offensive than the nose; no obviously serious defects.  Bit of sourness on the back end, and very quick to finish with a watery feel as it goes down.  Certainly there are worse beers from outside of Europe and the North America; the question is, how many are better and is it worth my while to try to find out?
One thing's for sure, if you go to a house party with this stuff, your going to get pointed out. It's a good conversation starter if anything. (not that i need help in that field)

There is something about this beer - no doubt. I'm giving it credit for saving my life once. It was the only drinkable beer around when I was travelling its country of origin. As a matter of factuarial accuracy I should add that the brewery was founded by Germans (which explains why it tastes like a beer).
Bleah- too rice-y for me.  Overpowering grainyness & bad aroma.  Light bitterness did not compensate.  Not good at all...

Average pilsner, nice balance, good aftertaste, not too bad
...............
It's the Pabst Blue Ribbon of China (even though PBR is available and brewed IN China).
Hoppy scent. Light in colour. Barley taste, flat. Unimpressive..............

An innocuous beer that does a nice job of cooling the bite of spicy curry and chili-pepper based dishes.  It deserves respect for that reason, but it's a fairly unremarkable and simple pilsener that, without the spicy food to go along with it, does little for a lover of good beer.
One of the nicest eastern lagers to drink with Chinese food! I love it!.....
Not too bad.  Slight "mechanical" taste at times.  Batches vary in consistency.
Almost an american premium style.  Slight sweet malt with a sweet noble hop finish.  A beer well suited for chop suey.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is clear light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (grain, light bread), lightly hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation. Reasonably clean and inoffensive, but unbalanced (sweet), adjuncty, and boring.
Yellow coloured. Rice aroma, ratehr sweet, not exactly full bodied. In some perverted way I still kinf of like it.

This beer has intimidated me for years with it's "Panda Piss" reputation. I have always assumed it sucked even without tasting it. Well, here goes....Decent color, a slight malty nose with floral traces, like slightly burnt toast. Not nearly as tasty as it smells, virtualy flat, sits like a stout but as a pils, has no right to. Taste...like chewing a piece of paper. I can see this bland, slightly sweet brew being a nice balance to fiery Sezshwan cusine. If it was the only beer offered and my mouth was on fire from spicy shrimp soup, I might drink it again. Other than that, I'll pass.

Never judge a book by its cover! Almost no aroma, barely any hopfeel (well hopped my ass) and an uninteresting overall flavor experience. Thank God I had my Stone IPA (Gusler) to fall back on when we got home: )
Not too bad, but I would not hunt it down...................................
Not a bad lager - touch of ginger?  I've only had it in Chinese restaurants, where it fits well.

My first Asian brew.  I was expecting something thin and watery, but was greeted with a pretty good beer, and it held its own while competing with spicy Chinese food.  A little skunky, but smooth enough so that you forget.  Good enough, but I wouldn't buy it anywhere except a Chinese place.
I had some of this at a chinese buffet and was pretty impressed.  I thought it was reasonably smooth but was a little skunky.  I was impressed for a chinese beer.

This beer has a nice, sweet aroma to it. The flavor, however, is watery, skunky and bitter in an unpleasant way. Why do crappy beers get so much acclaim just because they are imported? At lesat it has a pretty bottle....
This sucked. This really sucked. I couldnt even drink the whole bottle. Bland, bitter, nasty flavors. Terrible beer.

Useful when washing down your curry in the local Chinky.  Not entirely unpleasant (provided it's served v. cold), but since I've only ever had it to wash down spicy food, it's a bit hard to discern anything exceptional.

I bought this beer just for the fun of it - shipping beer all the way from China to Norway seems like the ultimate absurdity, if the beer isn't something extraordinary. This beer isn't. But Tsingtao is not outright bad either - it just isn't very interesting. Heineken-like aroma, neutral flavour, overly carbonated, no lasting head. Sure it would be refreshing on a summer's day in China - exporting it to Europe should be considered a waste of resources.
Introduced to this at a Chinese place in Newport.  A good match with Chinese food, I don't think I would drink it as a stand alone.
Chinese Pilsner?  Need I say more?  Drink it if it's the only thing that you can get at the local Chinese restaurant.
Usually skunky, but not as bad as some. Fairly OK for putting out Szechuan fires.
Very much a Chinese Heineken, with an interesting bitter taste, nothing special but worth a try

One of the only Chinese beers I’ve ever tried.  Light, dry and and very crisp with a hint of maltiness.  Mildly sweet finish.  One of the few beers that I will drink as cold as I can get it.  Love the way this one feels on the palate.
Quite sweet on the palate, best of the chinese beers, goes well with chinese food funny enough.

Not a bad beer.
Quite golden in colour with a very individualistic taste...
Very skunky. Do not get it in the can.......................................
Chinese really need moe western influence...the best chinese beer I have ever had...the only one.  Taste like carbonated won ton soup!!!

Soapy, rather unimpressive Chinese beer. Pronounced "Ching-Dao" if you wanna order it in a Chinese Resterant and look classy. Of course if the place has Budweiser, you'd be getting a better beer, and that ain't saying much.
