Best beer from China that i've had by a mile, and thats not saying much, went well with Chinese food though, but otherwise i couldn't see myself drinking it.

This should be called "China-ken". Very
similar flavor to Heineken, but more skunky.
Good with Chinese food as well as pep. pizza................................
Chineese Light.  This has a nice aroma that comes off much stronger than its taste.  This is quite light and crisp.

I love "Ching-Dow," especially with Chinese food.  It is a great  beer for what it is, and I am rating it as such.  It smells nice, and has a rich golden color and thick mouthfeel. It is what  regular beer should be.

I don't know why the other reviews are so negative. I found this beer to be crisp without much bitterness at all. I enjoyed it with a healthy portion of Thai food, the heavy spices of which may have made the beer more agreeable. It did seem a little over carbonated, but that can be forgiven I suppose. Probably the best Asian beer I've tasted.
good with chinese food and lots of msg.  has a strong malty aroma, and a slight bitter aftertaste. ok beer.
Tsingtao was actually the site of a German naval base which fell to the Japanese in the early days of WWI.  And that's about the most interesting thing I can say about this beer.

Hoppy aroma, though less hops apparent in the actual taste, which was inoffensive but lacking in character as well. A little bitter, and some hops present, but nothing to write home about. I think drinking it close to the country of origin helps (which I'm doing now)--I don't expect it to hold up so well far from China. Still, I would choose it over certain other mass-market brews, if that was my only choice.
My sample was not fresh , tasted stale . Stalle aroma notes as well (da ?!) . Would taste propablly better in China (fresh sample) , but was smooth ... few pts extra for that .
Can. Chinatown, London. Clear yellow with small white head. Acidic taste, cereal & signs of hop aroma.  Went very well with crispy aromatic duck.
Light fruity nose. Light front and mid. Light grainy end. Can be found fresh in the L.A. area, so quality was not bad at all.

Not for me.
I'd rather drink beers
from Germany and North America.........
A bland, unimpressive lager. Nothing remarkable.............................

On the one hand, this isn't a very flavorful beer.  On the other hand, it dosen't have offensive flavors (skunk, chemical) that are common in imported mass produced lagers.  An appropriate compliment to Chinese food.
Fruity and light beer that goes well with spicy chinese food. Without the food I wouldn't have touched it.
tried it twice..consistently bad...horrible value for the money.............
I really enjoy this beer with sushi due to it's light flavor.  It's flavor and body are very light but not watery.
decent lager, a bit sour, but decent nonetheless.  Over the Summer I busted out the 22 ounce at a party and people thought I was weird.  Id like to taste a really good chinese beer one day.
It has a bit of a sour finish, which distinguishes it.  Otherwise, a dry and drinkable lager.
It tasted old, and had no desirable qualities.  ............................

china i think has a very good beer here. Not strong and not too mild it is just right. Nice aroma and taste.
the taste stays till end. very smooth on the palate not harsh.
not watered down like some of the other people say it is.

Why buy this watery crapola when for the same price you can pick up a 12 pack of Shiner Bock or some other mediocre cheap beer? Not abysmal, I suppose, but inordinately expensive for what you get. Maybe heated like sake it would be better...naaaahhhhh...
As far from beer as China is from here. ....................................
Not as bad as I was expecting. Actually has somewhat of an interesting malt flavor, but not a great finish and fairly thin and headless.

Well, this was a lot better than I thought it would be.  It wasn't awesome, but it wasn't awful either.  The aroma was kind of boring,lightly hoppy, and the appearance was pretty aveagerage for a pilsner (decent color and clarity, as well as a decent head and lace).  The flavor I thought was actually very pleasant.  I even liked the slightly ricey aftertaste.  I was most impressed with the mouthfeell and how it complemented my dish so well (Orange beef with fried rice).  It's definitely not a beer that I'll have cravings for but I can seeing myself getting it again once and a while.
A nice lager, but I guess we from the west only drink it because it's from China.

much like any other bland mass produced  beers  
usually  available in chinese 
restaurants.
This beer was good. Nothing really stuck out to me about it. Its one of the few beers that i've had from that side of the world and it among the best of them.
Surprisingly fine beer. Clean color, very peculiar aroma and a refreshing taste. Worth a try.
Equivalent of a Moosehead or Labatt's Blue, but more expensive.  Why bother?

Quite decent, especially with
a nice spicy Chinese meal.  Very
refreshing and clean.
Communist China may suck, but their beer is okay with me. a nice change and good with spicy foods.
Not bad; not great. A small step above Yankee macrobrew, as there's a touch of flavor (hops?) to it.

Crisp, dry, and refreshing.  My first few sips of this reminded me of Heineken but surprisingly this did not develop the overly bitter, offensive aftertaste often accompanying that other beer in the green bottle. Slight malt and yeast presence, with a semi-hoppy finish.  I was pleased with how "not-bad" this was.
Is it because I'm not turned on by the Asian pilsener? Yes and no. It has more in common with Thai and Mexican beers than Japanese or Indian. Limp, weak beer.
This is not a bad beer if it is fresh. It beats water on the sweaty dance floor of life. Classic rice beer. light with little else to say for itself. Beats the American macros.
It's a slight step up from Budweiser and the like, but only a small step. A light beer without a whole lot of flavor.

Actually drank it in China, outside of the Brewery. OK beer, but tasted better because I was only paying about $1 for a 40oz bottle. Gave me a doozy of a hangover and did not go with any food I ate, I wouldn't drink it anywhere but in China!!
Nice clean beer but there's something missing that I can't quite place.    Also a bit lightly carbonated for my taste.  Maybe a bit dry in the finish also.

A decent beer.  I sometimes try it when I am in an oriental restaurant.  Definately not a beer that I would bring home and drink with my friends, but it does add to the atmosphere of eating at oriental restaurants.
I didn't know the Chineese made beer.  I'm still not sure.  It was a novelty at the Chineese restaurant.  What do you expect from commies??
A light tasting beer hovering just above water.    Nice clarity.............
Fair appearance and that is about it.  Keep[ it in China.  .................
You hear rumours that this beer is hoppy, but I just don't see it. But it's a long journey and a green bottle, so what can you possibly expect.
Typical Asian lager beer.  Light, watery, a little skunky.  Refreshing with hot Chinese or Thai food.  Good lawnmower beer.  Crisp and light.
bitter hop aroma, full-bodied, slightly bitter flavor.......................

I used to work in a Chinese/Vietnamese restaurant when I was a wee lass of 15. I would sneak a Tsingtao (Ching-dow) now and again. It was cool then, but not so cool now. I like it better than the AMerican Pils (I swear, I don't always slam American beer. Some of it is really good, just not the 'beers of the masses' i.e. Miller, Bud, etc.)It is a bit skunky, I must say. I really think that I am getting on 'its the green bottle' bandwagon.

Had this at a local chinese resteraunt. Wasn't all that impressed but it wasn't bad overall.  If it was a choice between this and something like bud or mich on the menu, I would either choose this or water..  depending on what I was eating at the time.
I had this at a chinese restaurant in Paris, France.  It was clean and refreshing, but not my favorite by all means.  Seemed to fit the meal though, which was nice.

The archetypal lager color a bright gold, typical head modest and bright white, frothy in texture, the lace thin. Nose is quintessential lager malt and crisp, start is sweet, top is cadaverous. Finish is moderate in carbonation, hops apropos to  the style, not a very good beer by any countries standards, but they sell a hell of a lot of it.

One word: Bland. I gave this beer a fighting chance, on more than one occasion. I tend to order this beer (or more like "force this stuff upon myself" because Chinese restaurants usually have CRAPPY beer selections) every time I go out for Chinese. And everytime I'm reminded how much I don't like it. I'm waiting for the Chinese Brewpub - then I can finally say I've seen it all.

A decent beer.  I sometimes try it when I am in an oriental restaurant.  Definately not a beer that I would bring home and drink with my friends, but it does add to the atmosphere of eating at oriental restaurants.
I didn't know the Chineese made beer.  I'm still not sure.  It was a novelty at the Chineese restaurant.  What do you expect from commies??

Fair appearance and that is about it.  Keep[ it in China.  .................
